docs.title: AsyncTask
docs.text:
This module provides a way to run tasks asynchronously.

Importing this module automatically enables --threaded flag of the compiler. Note that this causes some overhead even for a single-threaded program.

docs.title: _run_task_function : Std::Box (() -> Std::Ptr) -> Std::Ptr
docs.text: Evaluate the boxed lazy pointer.

docs.title: get : AsyncTask::Task a -> a
docs.text:
Gets the result of a task.

This function blocks the current thread until the task is finished.

docs.title: make : (() -> a) -> AsyncTask::Task a
docs.text:
Makes a task which performs a computation asynchronously.

Example:

module Main;
import AsyncTask;

main : IO ();
main = (
    let sum_range = |from, to| (
        loop((0, from), |(sum, i)| (
            if i == to { break $ sum };
            continue $ (sum + i, i + 1)
        ))
    );
    let n = 1000000000;
    // Compute the sum of numbers from 0 to n/2 - 1.
    // This task will be executed asynchronously (if you are using multi-core CPU).
    let sum_former = AsyncTask::make(|_| sum_range(0, n/2));
    // Compute the sum of numbers from n/2 to n.
    // We perfom this in the current thread while waiting for the result of the former task.
    let sum_latter = sum_range(n/2, n);
    // Sum up the results of the two computations.
    let sum = sum_former.get + sum_latter;
    // Then the sum should be n * (n - 1) / 2.
    assert_eq(|_|"", sum, n * (n - 1) / 2);;
    println $
        "Sum of numbers from 0 to " + (n - 1).to_string +
        " is " + sum_former.get.to_string + " + " + sum_latter.to_string +
        " = " + sum.to_string + "."
);

docs.title: number_of_processors : Std::I64
docs.text: Gets the number of processors (CPU cores) currently available. This is implemented by calling sysconf(_SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN). The runtime pools as many threads as this number to execute asynchronous tasks.

docs.title: get : AsyncTask::AsyncIOTask::IOTask a -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Get the result of an asynchronous I/O action.

docs.title: make : Std::IO a -> Std::IO (AsyncTask::AsyncIOTask::IOTask a)
docs.text:
An IO version of AsyncTask::make.

Example:

module Main;
import AsyncTask;

main : IO ();
main = (
    let print_ten : I64 -> IO () = |task_num| (
        loop_m(0, |i| (
            if i == 10 {
                break_m $ ()
            } else {
                let msg = "task number: " + task_num.to_string + ", i: " + i.to_string;
                msg.println;;
                continue_m $ i + 1
            }
        ))
    );
    (*AsyncIOTask::make(print_ten(0))).get;;
    (*AsyncIOTask::make(print_ten(1))).get;;
    pure()
);

docs.title: wait : (a -> Std::Bool) -> AsyncTask::Var::Var a -> Std::IO ()
docs.text:
var.wait(cond) waits until cond on the value of var is satisfied.

Note that it is not assured that cond is satisfied after wait returned; the value in var may be changed after cond is evaluated.

docs.title: wait_and_lock : (a -> Std::Bool) -> (a -> Std::IO b) -> AsyncTask::Var::Var a -> Std::IO b
docs.text: var.wait_and_lock(cond, act) waits until cond on the value of var is satisfied, then performs act on the value in var while locking var to prevent it from being changed by another thread.

docs.text: A native handle of a task. This type is used only for implementation.

docs.title: type Var a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text:
A type of variable which can be modified from multiple threads.

module Main;
import AsyncTask;

main : IO ();
main = (
    let logger = *Var::make([]); // A mutable array of strings.

    // Launch multiple threads, and log in which order each thread is executed.
    let num_threads = number_of_processors * 2;
    Iterator::range(0, num_threads).fold_m((), |i, _| (
        AsyncIOTask::make(
            logger.lock(|logs| (
                let count = logs.get_size;
                let msg = "Thread " + i.to_string + " is running at " + count.to_string +
                    if count % 10 == 1 { "st" } else if count % 10 == 2 { "nd" } else if count % 10 == 3 { "rd" } else { "th" };
                let msg = msg + if i == count { "." } else { "!" };
                logger.set(logs.push_back(msg))
            ))
        )
    ));;

    // Wait until all threads are finished.
    +logger.wait(|logs| logs.get_size == num_threads);

    println $ (*logger.get).to_iter.join("\n")
);

docs.title: type BinaryHeap p e = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text:
The binary heap.

The first type parameter is the type of the priority object to be used. The type must implement the Priority trait.

The priority objects that prioritize the maximum or minimum value based on comparison with the LessThan trait are provided in this module (PriorityMaximum and PriorityMinimum). It is recommended to use the MaxBinaryHeap and MinBinaryHeap type aliases when using them.

docs.title: binomial_coefficients : Std::I64 -> Std::Array (Std::Array Std::I64)
docs.text:
Calculates table (2-dimensional array) of binomial coefficients.

Deprecated: this function will be moved to another project in the future.

binomial_coefficients(m) evaluates to an array of arrays table where table.@(n).@(r) is the binomial coefficient "binom(n, r)" for 0 <= n <= m and 0 <= r <= n. Here m has to be less than or equal to 66 to avoid overflow.

Minilib.Collection.RBTree
docs.text:
Red-Black Tree. (This is an internal module of TreeMap and TreeSet.)

Ported from Japanese translation of the book below:

"Purely functional data structures" by Chris Okasaki, Cambridge University Press, 1998, ISBN 0-521-66350-4

And for removal algorithm, ported from web site below. http://wwwa.pikara.ne.jp/okojisan/rb-tree/index.html#Delete

NOTE: less_than() function must meet following conditions. - Irreflexivity: for all x, less_than(x,x) must be false. - Asymmetry: for all x, y, if less_than(x,y) is true, then less_than(y,x) must be false. - Transitivity: for all x, y, z, if less_than(x,y) is true and less_than(y,z) is true, then less_than(x,z) must be true.

docs.title: _Debug : Std::Bool
docs.text: Debug flag. If set to true, a lot of debug messages will be printed and various validations will be done.

docs.title: _debug_assert_level_diff : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] Std::String -> Std::String -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::String -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::I64 -> Std::Lazy b -> b
_debug_eprintln_lazy : (() -> Std::String) -> ()
docs.text: Prints to stderr if the debug flag is set.

docs.title: _fast_append : Std::Iterator::DynIterator a -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator a -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator a
docs.text: Same as Iterator::append but a little fast.

docs.title: _less_than : [a : Std::LessThan, a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] a -> a -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Default less_than function using LessThan trait.

docs.title: _remove_fix_left : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a) -> (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a)
docs.text: Called when node.left.level == node.right.level - 1. Returns (active, fixed) where fixed is the fixed node, and active is true iff fixed.level = node.level - 1.

docs.title: _remove_fix_right : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a) -> (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a)
docs.text: Called when node.right.level == node.level.level - 1. Returns (active, fixed) where fixed is the fixed node, and active is true iff fixed.level = node.level - 1.

docs.title: _remove_max : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a, a)
docs.text: node._remove_max removes an maximum element. Returns (active, removed, max) where removed is the node after removal, max is the maximum element, and active is true iff removed.level == node.level - 1.

docs.title: _remove_min : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a, a)
docs.text: node._remove_min removes an minimum element. Returns (active, removed, min) where removed is the node after removal, min is the minimum element, and active is true iff removed.level == node.level - 1.

docs.title: _to_array_inner : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] Std::Array a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Array a

_try_remove_range : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] (a -> Std::Bool) -> (a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Option (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a)
docs.text: node._try_remove_range(lt_begin, lt_end) tries to remove single element elem where !elem.lt_begin && elem.lt_end is true. Even if there are several elements that holds the condition, only one of them are removed. Returns some((active, removed)) if removal is succeeded where removed is the node after removal, and active is true iff removed.level == node.level - 1. Returns none() if removal is failed.

docs.title: _try_remove_range_inner : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] (a -> Std::Bool) -> (a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Option (Std::Bool, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a)
_upsert_inner : a -> (a -> a) -> (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
find : a -> (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Option a
docs.text: node.find(x, less_than) finds an element elem that is equivalent to x, ie. !less_than(elem, x) && !less_than(x, elem) is true.

docs.title: find_range : (a -> Std::Bool) -> (a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator a
docs.text: node.find_range(lt_begin, lt_end) finds all elements elem such that !elem.lt_begin && elem.lt_end is true. NOTE: lt_begin and lt_end must meet following condition: for all x, x.lt_begin is true then x.lt_end must be true.

docs.title: find_range_descending : (a -> Std::Bool) -> (a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator a
docs.text: node.find_range(lt_begin, lt_end) finds all elements elem such that !elem.lt_begin && elem.lt_end is true, in descending order. NOTE: lt_begin and lt_end must meet following condition: for all x, x.lt_begin is true then x.lt_end must be true.

docs.title: from_iter : [a : Std::LessThan, a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem, it : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item it = a] it -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
from_iter_lt : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem, it : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item it = a] (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> it -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
get_color : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> (Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a, a, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
get_first : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Option a
docs.text: Gets the first element (that is, the smallest element) of the tree.

docs.title: get_last : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::Option a
docs.text: Gets the last element (that is, the largest element) of the tree.

docs.title: get_size : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::I64
docs.text: Gets the number of elements.

docs.title: get_triplet : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> (Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a, a, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a)
docs.text: If the node is black or red, node.get_triplet returns a triplet (left, elem, right). If the node is empty, it will abort.

docs.title: insert : [a : Std::LessThan, a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
docs.text: node.insert(x) inserts an element x using default LessThan ordering. If node already contains an element y equivalent to x, ie. !(x < y) && !(y < x) is true, then y is replaced with x.

docs.title: insert_lt : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] a -> (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
docs.text: node.insert_lt(x, less_than) inserts an element x using less_than ordering. If node already contains an element y equivalent to x, ie. !less_than(x,y) && !less_than(y,x) is true, then y is replaced with x.

docs.title: level : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::I64
docs.text: Returns the level of this node (ie. the number of black nodes from this node to any leaf). Panicks when the left and right nodes have different black count.

docs.title: level_nonvalidate : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Std::I64
docs.text: Returns the level of this node (ie. the number of black nodes from this node to any leaf). This function does not validate, so an unbalanced node can be specified.

docs.title: remove : [a : Std::LessThan, a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
docs.text: node.remove(x) removes any element y equivalent to x, ie. !(x < y) && !(y < x) is true.

docs.title: remove_lt : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] a -> (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
docs.text: node.remove_lt(x, less_than) removes any element y equivalent to x, ie. ie. !less_than(x,y) && !less_than(y,x) is true.

docs.title: remove_range : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] (a -> Std::Bool) -> (a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
docs.text: node.remove_range(lt_begin, lt_end) removes all elements elem where !elem.lt_begin && elem.lt_end is true. NOTE: lt_begin and lt_end must meet following condition: for all x, x.lt_begin is true then x.lt_end must be true.

docs.title: set_color : ((Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a, a, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a

set_triplet : (Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a, a, Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
upsert : [a : Std::LessThan, a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] a -> (a -> a) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
docs.text: node.upsert(x, updater) inserts or updates using default LessThan ordering. If node does not contain an element equivalent to x, x is inserted. If node already contains an element y equivalent to x, ie. !(x < y) && !(y < x) is true, then y is updated with updater(y).

docs.title: upsert_lt : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] a -> (a -> a) -> (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a
docs.text: node.upsert_lt(x, less_than) inserts or updates using less_than ordering. If node does not contain an element equivalent to x, x is inserted. If node already contains an element y equivalent to x, ie. !less_than(x,y) && !less_than(y,x) is true, then y is updated with updater(y).

docs.title: validate : [a : Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNodeElem] (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.RBTree::RBNode::RBNode a -> (Std::I64, Std::Option a, Std::Option a)
docs.text: Validates that: - the left and right nodes have same black count - children of a red node is not red - max of left node < elem - elem < min of right node Returns (level, min, max). Panicks if validation failed.

docs.title: type RBNode a = box union { ...variants... }
docs.text: A type of red-black tree node.

docs.title: Minilib.Collection.TreeMap
docs.text: TreeMap is a map that manages keys in sorted order.

docs.title: _lift_lt : (k -> k -> Std::Bool) -> (k, v) -> (k, v) -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Converts key_less_than to entry_less_than.

docs.title: contains_key : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] k -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Checks whether a TreeMap contains a key.

docs.title: erase : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] k -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v
docs.text:
Erases an entry from a TreeMap. For example, tm.erase(k) removes an entry (k,v) from tm.

NOTE: If tm contains an entry (k1,v1) where the key k1 is equivalent to k, ie. !less_than(k,k1) && !less_than(k1,k) is true, then (k1,v1) is removed.

docs.title: find : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] k -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Option v
docs.text: Finds an element from a TreeMap.

docs.title: find_range : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] k -> k -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator (k, v)
docs.text: tm.find_range(begin, end) finds all entries (k,v) where !less_than(k, begin) && less_than(k, end) is true. In default LessThan ordering, that condition is same as begin <= k && k < end.

docs.title: find_raw_range : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] ((k, v) -> Std::Bool) -> ((k, v) -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator (k, v)
docs.text: tm.find_raw_range(lt_begin, lt_end) finds all entries (k,v) where !lt_begin((k, v)) && lt_end((k, v)) is true. NOTE: lt_begin and lt_end must meet following condition: for all (k,v), lt_begin((k,v)) is true then lt_end((k,v)) must be true.

docs.title: from_iter : [k : Std::LessThan, k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue, it : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item it = (k, v)] it -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v
docs.text: Converts an iterator of key-value pairs into a TreeMap using default LessThan ordering.

docs.title: from_iter_lt : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue, it : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item it = (k, v)] (k -> k -> Std::Bool) -> it -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v
docs.text: Converts an iterator of key-value pairs into a TreeMap using specified ordering.

docs.title: get_size : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::I64
docs.text: Gets the number of entries.

docs.title: insert : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] k -> v -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v
docs.text:
Inserts an entry into a TreeMap. For example, tm.insert(k, v) inserts an entry (k,v) into tm.

NOTE: If tm already contains an entry (k1,v1) where the key k1 is equivalent to k, ie. !less_than(k,k1) && !less_than(k1,k) is true, then (k1,v1) is replaced with (k,v).

docs.title: is_empty : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Checks whether a TreeMap is empty.

docs.title: keys : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator k
docs.text: Returns an iterator of keys in ascending order.

docs.title: make : [k : Std::LessThan, k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] () -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v
docs.text: TreeMap::make() creates an empty TreeMap using default LessThan ordering.

docs.title: make_lt : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] (k -> k -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v
docs.text: TreeMap::make_lt(less_than) creates an empty TreeMap using specified ordering. NOTE: less_than function must meet specific conditions. For details, see documentation of RBTree.

docs.title: to_array : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Array (k, v)
docs.text: Converts a TreeMap into an array of key-value pairs in ascending order of keys.

docs.title: to_iter : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator (k, v)
docs.text: Converts a TreeMap into an iterator of key-value pairs in ascending order of keys.

docs.title: upsert : [k : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapKey, v : Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMapValue] k -> v -> (v -> v) -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v -> Minilib.Collection.TreeMap::TreeMap::TreeMap k v
docs.text:
Inserts or updates an entry in a TreeMap. For example, tm.upsert(k, v, updater) inserts an entry (k,v) into tm.

NOTE: If tm already contains an entry (k1,v1) where the key k1 is equivalent to k, ie. !less_than(k,k1) && !less_than(k1,k) is true, then (k1,v1) is replaced with (k, updater(v1)).

docs.title: type TreeMap k v = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: TreeMap is a structure that stores key-value pairs into a red-black tree.

docs.title: Minilib.Collection.TreeSet
docs.text: TreeSet is a set that manages elements in sorted order.

docs.title: contains : [a : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSetElem] a -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Checks whether a TreeSet contains an element.

docs.title: erase : [a : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSetElem] a -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a
docs.text:
Erases an element from a TreeSet. For example, ts.erase(x) removes x from ts.

NOTE: If ts contains an element y equivalent to x, ie. !less_than(x,y) && !less_than(y,x) is true, then y is removed.

docs.title: find_range : [a : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSetElem] a -> a -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator a
docs.text: ts.find_range(begin, end) finds all elements x where !less_than(x, begin) && less_than(x, end) is true. In default LessThan ordering, that condition is same as begin <= x && x < end.

docs.title: find_raw_range : [a : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSetElem] (a -> Std::Bool) -> (a -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator a
docs.text: ts.find_raw_range(lt_begin, lt_end) finds all elements x where !lt_begin(x) && lt_end(x) is true. NOTE: lt_begin and lt_end must meet following condition: for all x, x.lt_begin is true then x.lt_end must be true.

docs.title: from_iter : [a : Std::LessThan, a : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSetElem, it : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item it = a] it -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a
docs.text: Converts an iterator into a TreeSet using default LessThan ordering.

docs.title: from_iter_lt : [a : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSetElem, it : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item it = a] (a -> a -> Std::Bool) -> it -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a

docs.title: get_size : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a -> Std::I64

docs.text:
Inserts an element into a TreeSet. For example, ts.insert(x) inserts x into ts.

NOTE: If ts already contains an element y equivalent to x, ie. !less_than(x,y) && !less_than(y,x) is true, then y is replaced with x.

docs.title: intersect : [a : Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSetElem] Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a -> Minilib.Collection.TreeSet::TreeSet::TreeSet a

docs.title: Minilib.Common.Assert
docs.text: Assert functions.

docs.title: assert_eq_lazy : [a : Std::Eq] Std::Lazy Std::String -> a -> a -> Std::Lazy b -> b
docs.text: assert_eq_lazy(errmsg, lhs, rhs, lazy_func) asserts that two values are equal. If the assertion failed, prints a message to the stderr and aborts the program. If the assertion succeeded, calls a lazy function. For example, instead of eval *assert_eq(|_| "error", a, b); ... in an IO monad, you can write assert_eq_lazy(|_| "error", a, b) $ |_| ....

docs.title: assert_lazy : Std::Lazy Std::String -> Std::Bool -> Std::Lazy a -> a
docs.text:
assert_lazy(errmsg, value, lazy_func) asserts that a condition (boolean value) is true. If the assertion failed, prints a message to the stderr and aborts the program. If the assertion succeeded, calls a lazy function.

For example, instead of eval *assert(|_| "error", a == b); ... in an IO monad, you can write assert_lazy(|_| "error", a == b) $ |_| ....

docs.title: Minilib.Common.Common
docs.text: Common functions such as id and flip.

docs.title: apply : a -> (a -> b) -> b
docs.text: apply(a, f) is equal to f(a). You can write it as apply(a) $ f, a.apply $ f or f.apply(a).

docs.title: compose2 : (a -> b -> c) -> (c -> d) -> a -> b -> d
docs.text: compose2 composes a two-argument function with a one-argument function.

docs.title: const : a -> b -> a
docs.text: const is a constant function. It returns its first argument ignoring its second argument. ie. const(a,b) returns a. Note that const(id)(a,b) returns b, since const(id)(a,b) = const(id,a)(b) = id(b) = b.

docs.title: curry : ((a, b) -> c) -> a -> b -> c
docs.text: curry converts an uncurried function to a curried function.

docs.title: flip : (a -> b -> c) -> b -> a -> c
docs.text: flip(f) swaps the first argument and the second argument.

docs.title: id : a -> a
docs.text: id is an identity function.

docs.title: pair : a -> b -> (a, b)
docs.text: pair(a,b) returns (a, b).

docs.title: swap : (a, b) -> (b, a)
docs.text: swap is a function that swaps the first component and the second component of Tuple2. ie. (a,b).swap returns (b, a).

docs.title: uncurry : (a -> b -> c) -> (a, b) -> c
docs.text: uncurry converts a curried function to an uncurried function.

docs.title: Minilib.Common.TimeEx
docs.text: Timing module, such as sleep for a while, and measuring execution time.

docs.title: consumed_realtime_while_io : Std::IO a -> Std::IO (a, Std::F64)
docs.text: Get wall-clock time elapsed while executing an I/O action.

docs.title: measure_time : Std::F64 -> (() -> a) -> Std::IO (Std::F64, a)
docs.text: Measures wall-clock time per a function call. Specifically, It calls the function many times until the specified time limit (in second) passes and measures the total time. Returns the measured time per loop (in second) and the IO operation result. NOTE: The measured time per loop has a overhead about 0.1~1.0 usec.

docs.title: measure_time_io : Std::F64 -> Std::IO a -> Std::IO (Std::F64, a)
docs.text: Measures wall-clock time per an IO operation. Specifically, It performs an IO operation many times until the specified time limit (in second) passes and measures the total time. Returns the measured time per loop (in second) and the IO operation result. NOTE: The measured time per loop has a overhead about 0.1~1.0 usec.

docs.title: notimeit : [a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> (() -> a) -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Same interface as timeit() but does not measure time.

docs.title: timeit : [a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> (() -> a) -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Measures wall-clock time per a function call. Specifically, It calls the function many times and measures the total time. It then prints the function result and measured time per loop. NOTE: The measured time per loop has a overhead about 0.1~1.0 usec.

docs.title: timeit_io : [a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> Std::IO a -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Measures wall-clock time per an IO operation. Specifically, It performs an IO operation many times and measures the total time. It then prints the IO operation result and measured time per loop. NOTE: The measured time per loop has a overhead about 0.1~1.0 usec.

docs.title: usleep : Std::U32 -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Sleeps for specified micro-seconds. For details, see Linux manual page for usleep().

docs.text: Performs carryless multiplication of U64 and U64. z is used as a buffer for setting the result. NOTE: the bit order is reversed, ie. bit 0 is MSB, bit (n-1) is LSB.

docs.text: get the authentication tag

docs.title: gcm_ad : (Minilib.Crypto.AES.GCM::Block -> Minilib.Crypto.AES.GCM::Block) -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg (Std::Array Std::U8)
docs.text: Performs authenticated decryption. Input: - cipher: 128-bit block cipher - iv: initialization vector, typically 96 bits - ciphertext: a byte sequence which will be decrypted - auth_data: a byte sequence which will not be encrypted - tag: authentication tag Output: ok(plaintext) or err(ErrMsg) - ok(plaintext): decrypted byte sequence - err(ErrMsg): inauthenticity

docs.title: gcm_ae : (Minilib.Crypto.AES.GCM::Block -> Minilib.Crypto.AES.GCM::Block) -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::I64 -> (Std::Array Std::U8, Std::Array Std::U8)
docs.text: Performs authenticated encryption. Input: - cipher: 128-bit block cipher - iv: initialization vector, typically 96 bits - plaintext: a byte sequence which will be encrypted - auth_data: a byte sequence which will not be encrypted - len_t: tag length in bits Output: (c, t) - c: ciphertext - t: authentication tag

docs.title: type Block = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: A block is a bit string of 128 bits. We use two U64 as a representation. When converted to a bit string, it is encoded in big-endian. If a byte sequence is encoded to a bit string, MSB of the first byte becomes the leftmost bit.

docs.title: _match_quoted_char_u16 : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::U16
docs.text: Parse a quoted character. ("\n", "\uD83D" etc.) NOTE: Escape sequences of the form "\uXXXX" can only represent the range U+0000 to U+FFFF. Characters in the range U+10000 to U+10FFFF become surrogate pairs and are split like "\uD83D\uDE38". Therefore, we first interpret these strings as UTF16. Later convert it to UTF32 and join the surrogate pair, then convert it to UTF8.

docs.title: Minilib.Encoding.Xml
docs.text:
Simple XML Model.

This module is intended to support Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1 (Second Edition), but it is not fully supported at this time.

This module is not intended to support DOM API.

This module does not support XML namespace (xmlns).

docs.title: escape_special : Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text: Escapes XML special characters. eg. & -> &, < -> <, > -> >, \" -> ", ' -> '

docs.title: unescape_special : Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text: Unescapes XML special characters. eg. & -> &, < -> <, > -> >, " -> \", ' -> '. NOTE: Other character references is also converted.

docs.title: Minilib.Math.BigFloat
docs.text:
Arbitrary-precision floating point number.

A BigFloat is composed from a mantissa and the exponent of base 2.

Each BigFloat has a precision. It is same as the precision of the mantissa, and determined by the length of the underlying array (= BigNat).

The precision of a BigNat can be changed with set_prec().

For unary operator such as -a, the precision of the result is the same as the precision of the operand.

For binary operator such as a + b, a - b, a * b, a / b, the precision of the result is the maximum precision of the two operands.

docs.title: _append_last_zeros : Std::I64 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Appends trailing zeros until the size of the array is at least the specified size.

docs.title: _approx_with_exp : Std::I64 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> (Std::U64, Std::I64)
docs.text: Approximate BigNat a as m * 2^e. m is the mantissa and its type is U64. e is the expopnent and its type is I64. If the bitlength of a is smaller or equal to m_bitlen, returns (a._to_u64, 0). It should be hold that m * e^2 <= a < (m+1) * e^2.

docs.title: _base : Std::U64
docs.text: The base of BigNat. It must be power of 2.

docs.title: _bit_length : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U64
docs.text: Returns the bit length of a, ie. one plus the bit position of most significant 1. Returns 0 if a is zero.

docs.title: _cmp : (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::I64) -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::I64) -> Std::I64
docs.text: Calculates sign(a0 * _base ^ offset0 - a1 * _base ^ offset1).

docs.title: _convert_borrow_to_sign : (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::U64) -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::I64)
docs.text: Converts a result of a borrowed subtraction to a signed subtraction.

docs.title: _divmod : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::Array Std::U32)
docs.text: Calculates (a0 / a1, a0 % a1). Aborts if any error occured.

docs.title: _divmod_base : Std::U64 -> (Std::U64, Std::U64)
docs.text: divmod by _base.

docs.title: _divmod_by_power_of_two : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U64 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::Array Std::U32)
docs.text: Calculates (a0 / 2 ^ exp, a0 % 2 ^ exp). Aborts if any error occured.

docs.title: _divmod_by_two : Std::Array Std::U32 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::Array Std::U32)
docs.text: Calculates (a0 / 2, a0 % 2). Aborts if any error occured.

docs.title: _divmod_log2_base : Std::U64 -> (Std::U64, Std::U64)
docs.text: divmod by _log2_base.

docs.title: _divmod_u32 : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U32 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::U32)
docs.text: Calculates (a0 / d1, a0 % d1).

docs.title: _from_string_inner : Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg (Std::Array Std::U32)
docs.text: FromString of BigNat.

docs.title: _from_u64 : Std::U64 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Converts U64 to BigNat.

docs.title: _generate_bignat_range : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Random::Random -> (Random::Random, Std::Array Std::U32)
_is_zero : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Returns true if BigNat is zero.

docs.title: _log2_base : Std::U64
docs.text: log2 of base. It must be power of 2 and 0 <= _log2_base <= 32.

docs.title: _log2_log2_base : Std::U64
docs.text: log2(log2(base)). It must be 0 <= _log2_log2_base <= 5.

docs.title: _mul : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Calculates a0 * a1.

docs.title: _mul_u32 : Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Calculates d0 * a1.

docs.title: _neg : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Treats a as a negative number in two's complement representation and reverses its sign.

docs.title: _one : Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: 1 in BigNat.

docs.title: _pow_by_U64 : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U64 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Calculates a^n.

docs.title: _remove_last_zeros : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Removes trailing zeros.

docs.title: _signed_sub_with_offset : (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::I64) -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::I64) -> ((Std::Array Std::U32, Std::I64), Std::I64)
docs.text: Calculates a0 * pow(_base, offset0) - a1 * pow(_base, offset1). returns the result and the sign.

docs.title: _sub : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32
docs.text: Calculates a0 - a1. Aborts if the result is negative.

docs.title: _sub_u32_with_offset : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U32 -> Std::I64 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::U64)
docs.text: _sub_u32_with_offset(a, b, b_offset) calculates a - b * pow(_base, b_offset). returns the result and the borrow.

docs.title: _sub_u64_with_exp : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U64 -> Std::U64 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::U64)
docs.text: _sub_u64_with_exp(a, bm, be) calculates a - bm * pow(2, be). Returns the result and the borrow.

docs.title: _sub_with_exp_mul : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U64 -> Std::U64 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::U64)
docs.text: _sub_with_exp_mul(a, b, qm, qe) calculates a - b * qm * pow(2, qe). Returns the result and the borrow.

docs.title: _sub_with_offset_mul : Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::Array Std::U32 -> Std::U32 -> Std::I64 -> (Std::Array Std::U32, Std::U64)
docs.text: _sub_with_offset_mul(a, b, q, b_offset) calculates a - b * q * pow(_base, b_offset). Returns the result and the borrow.

docs.text: ToString of BigNat.

docs.text: Creates a complex number.

docs.title: Minilib.Math.Euclid
docs.text:
Euclid algorithms, such as gcd (greatest common divisor).

Euclid represents a Euclidean domain, which is a Ring with following division-with-remainder.

forall a b, a = (a / b) * b + (a % b)

For details, see Wikipedia: Euclidean domain.

docs.title: _extended_euclid_inner : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Euclid] a -> a -> (a, a, a)
docs.text: An internal function for extended_euclid.

docs.title: extended_euclid : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Euclid] a -> a -> (a, a, a)
docs.text: extended_euclid(a,b) performs Extended Euclidean algorithm. It solves a * x + b * y = d where d = gcd(a, b), and returns (x, y, d).

docs.title: gcd : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Euclid] a -> a -> a
docs.text: gcd(a,b) calculates the greatest common divisor of a and b.

docs.title: Minilib.Math.Modular
docs.text:
This is an arithmetic with a modulus (modulo), for example 2 * 5 = 10 = 3 (mod 7).

For details, see Wikipedia: Modular Arithmetic.

docs.title: _get_modulus : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Euclid] Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular a -> Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular a -> a
docs.text: Returns modulus of either x or y.

docs.title: make : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Euclid] a -> a -> Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular a
docs.text: Modular::make(v, m) creates v modulo m. It is an equivalence class of a quotient ring Z/mZ.

docs.title: modulo : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Euclid] a -> a -> Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular a
docs.text: Synonym for Modular::make.

docs.title: nonneg : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Euclid, a : Std::LessThan] Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular a -> Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular a
docs.text: x.nonneg changes @value with a equivalent non-negative value. For example, modulo(-1, 3) will be changed to modulo(2,3) because -1 == 2 mod 3.

docs.title: type Modular a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: A type that performs Modular Arithmetic.

docs.title: Minilib.Math.Polynomial
docs.text: Polynomial of one variable, for example x^2 + 2x + 1. The coefficients can be any ring.

docs.title: _to_string_full : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring, a : Std::ToString] Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a -> Std::String
docs.text: Converts a polynomial to a string without simplification.

docs.title: _to_string_simple : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring, a : Std::ToString] Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a -> Std::String
docs.text: Converts a polynomial to a string with simplification.

docs.title: at_degree : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring] Std::I64 -> a -> Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a
docs.text: a.at_degree(n) creates a polynomial a * x ^ n.

docs.title: generate : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator (Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial (Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular Std::I64))
docs.text: generate(p,m) generates polynomials of degree m or lower in GF(p).

docs.title: generate_primitive_polynomials : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator (Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial (Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular Std::I64))
docs.text: generate_primitive_polynomials(p, m) generates primitive polynomials of degree m in GF(p).

docs.title: get : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring] Std::I64 -> Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a -> a
docs.text: f.get(i) returns the coefficient of degree i.

docs.title: get_degree : Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a -> Std::I64
docs.text: f.get_degree returns the degree of a polynomial f.

docs.title: is_primitive : Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial (Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular Std::I64) -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Checks whether it is a primitive polynomial.

docs.title: make : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring] Std::Array a -> Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a
docs.text: Polynomial::make(coeff) creates a polynomial from coefficients. For example, Polynomial::make([1,2,3]) makes a polynomial 3x^2 + 2x + 1. For polynomials with degree greater than zero, the coefficient array is truncated so that the coefficient of highest degree is not zero.

docs.title: polynomial : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring] Std::Array a -> Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a
docs.text: Synonym for Polynomial::make.

docs.title: set : [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring] Std::I64 -> a -> Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a -> Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a
docs.text: f.set(i, a) sets the coefficient of degree i.

docs.title: subst : Std::I64 -> Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial (Minilib.Math.Modular::Modular Std::I64) -> Std::I64
docs.text: f.subst(x) substitutes the indeterminate of a polynomial with x.

docs.title: type Polynomial a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: A structure that represents a polynomial over a ring. The coefficient array is ascending order of degree. For example, [1,2,3] means a polynomial 3x^2 + 2x + 1.

docs.title: impl [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Field] Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a : Minilib.Math.Types::DivMod
docs.text: divmod(num, den) calculates a quotient quo = num / den and a reminder rem = num % den. Returns (quo, rem). The type of coefficients must be a field. If the division of the field does not fulfill the requirement (ie. forall a b, a == a / b * b), this function may return an incorrect result.

docs.title: impl [a : Minilib.Math.Types::Ring, a : Std::ToString] Minilib.Math.Polynomial::Polynomial a : Std::ToString

Minilib.Math.Ring
docs.text:
Functions for a ring, for example multiplication or exponent with an integer.

A ring is a mathematical structure which has addition(add), subtraction(sub), additive inverse(neg), additive unit(zero), multiplication(mul), multiplicative unit(one).

For details, see Wikipedia: Ring.

docs.title: pow_by_U64 : [a : Std::Mul, a : Minilib.Math.Types::One] Std::U64 -> a -> a
docs.text: a.pow_by_U64(n) calculates a ^ n.

docs.title: repeat_by_U64 : (a -> a -> a) -> a -> a -> Std::U64 -> a
docs.text: repeat_by_U64(op, x, a, n) calculates x.op(a).op(a)... for n times. op is an associative binary operation. This function returns the same result as Iterator::range(0, n).fold(x, |_, x| x.op(a)), but faster.

docs.title: times_by_U64 : [a : Std::Add, a : Std::Zero] Std::U64 -> a -> a
docs.text: a.times_by_U64(n) calculates a * n.

docs.text: divmod(a, b) returns (a/b, a%b).

docs.title: trait a : DivMod
docs.text: A trait for division-with-remainder.

docs.title: method divmod : a -> a -> (a, a)
docs.text: divmod(a, b) returns (a/b, a%b).

docs.title: Minilib.Media.Png
docs.text:
PNG image I/O.

How to use: 1. Install PNG library. For example, run the command below. $ sudo apt install libpng-dev 2. Add -d png option to fix run and fix build arguments.

NOTE: Currently only writing is supported. Reading is not supported yet.

Minilib.Media.Svg
docs.text:
Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) 1.1

This module uses Minilib.Encoding.Xml to handle XML.

docs.title: _append : Std::String -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: Appends an string to PathData.

docs.title: arcto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum, b : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum, r : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> r -> b -> b -> a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: pathdata.arcto(rx, ry, x_axis_rotation, large_arc_flag, sweep_flag, x, y) draws a elliptical arc. Coordinates are absolute. For details, see W3C SVG 1.1: 8.3.8 The elliptical arc curve commands.

docs.title: closepath : Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: pathdata.closepath ends the current sub-path by connecting it back to its initial point.

docs.title: curveto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> a -> a -> a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: pathdata.curveto(x1, y1, x2, y2, x, y) draws a cubic Bézier curve from the current point to (x,y) using (x1,y1) as the control point at the beginning of the curve and (x2,y2) as the control point at the end of the curve. Coordinates are absolute.

docs.title: empty : Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: PathData::empty is an empty PathData.

docs.title: lineto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: pathdata.lineto(x, y) draws a line from the current point to the given (x,y) coordinates which becomes the new current point. Coordinates are absolute.

docs.title: moveto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: pathdata.moveto(x, y) starts a new sub-path at the given (x,y) coordinates. Coordinates are absolute.

docs.title: newpath : Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: Synonym for PathData::empty.

docs.title: quadto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: pathdata.quadto(x1, y1, x, y) draws a quadratic Bézier curve from the current point to (x,y) using (x1,y1) as the control point. Coordinates are absolute.

docs.title: rlineto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: Same as lineto but coordinates are relative.

docs.title: rmoveto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: Same as moveto but coordinates are relative.

docs.title: scurveto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData

docs.title: squadto : [a : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum] a -> a -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData -> Minilib.Media.Svg::PathData
docs.text: Shorthand/smooth version of quadto.

docs.text: An array is converted to a string by joining elements with ", ". For example, [(123.45, 100.00), (234.60, 345.70)] -> "123.45 100, 234.6 345.7".

docs.title: impl Std::Bool : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum
docs.text: Bool is converted to either "1" or "0". For example, true -> "1", false -> "0".

docs.title: impl Std::F64 : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum
docs.text: F64 is converted to a decimal string. Trailing zeros and trailing periods are stripped. For example, 123.45 -> "123.45", 100.00 -> "100".

docs.title: impl Std::I64 : Minilib.Media.Svg::SvgNum
docs.text: I64 is converted to a decimal string. For example, 100 -> "100".

docs.text: call_cc(f) calls f with the current continuation, and returns a continuation monad. f takes the current continuation (the exit function) and should return a continuation monad. For example, call_cc(|exit| ... if condition { exit(false) }; ... pure(true)). The exit function can be passed to another function.

docs.text:
An implementation of MonadRandomIF for the StateT monad.

A state monad StateT rg m can be used as a MonadRandom, if the state rg implements Rng trait, and the target monad m is compatible to RngResult. The result type of Rng is lifted to the target monad m by the lifter.

docs.title: lens_state : ((s -> Minilib.Functor.Pair::PairLT a Minilib.Monad.Identity::Identity s) -> t -> Minilib.Functor.Pair::PairLT a Minilib.Monad.Identity::Identity t) -> Minilib.Monad.State::State s a -> Minilib.Monad.State::State t a

lens_state_t : [m : Std::Monad, m : Std::Functor] ((s -> Minilib.Functor.Pair::PairLT a m s) -> t -> Minilib.Functor.Pair::PairLT a m t) -> Minilib.Monad.State::StateT s m a -> Minilib.Monad.State::StateT t m a
docs.text:
Transforms a state monad with a lens action. For example, if Foo has a field bar: Bar, then act_bar is a function of type [f: Functor] (Bar -> f Bar) -> (Foo -> f Foo). Using act_bar, a state monad of Bar can be transformed to a state monad of Foo.

change_bar: StateT Bar IO ();
change_bar = ...;
change_foo: StateT Foo IO ();
change_foo = change_bar.lens_state_t(Foo::act_bar);

Note that act_xxx can be composed, for example Foo::act_bar << Bar::act_baz << Baz::act_qux.

docs.text: Simple HTTP server. The interface is similar to express of Node.js. - Insert a request handler on specific path - Listen for incoming requests

docs.text:
app.listen(server_host_port) listens for incoming requests, and respond to accepted connections.

This function sets the signal handler for SIGPIPE to SIG_IGN to avoid abnormal program termination when writing to a closed socket.

docs.title: _send_headers : Minilib.Net.Request::Response -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Request::Response

docs.title: content_type : Std::String -> Minilib.Net.Request::Response -> Minilib.Net.Request::Response
docs.text: response.content_type(type) sets the Content-Type header. You can specify an alias for the content type (e.g. "text", "json"). See the definition of _CONTENT_TYPE_ALIASES for a list of available aliases.

docs.title: end : Minilib.Net.Request::Response -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Request::Response

docs.title: Minilib.Net.Tcp
docs.text:
IPv4 TCP Socket operations.

Features: - IP address, port number - Resolves IP address from hostname - IPv4 Socket address - IPv4 TCP Socket

Tested platform: x86_64-linux-gnu, aarch64-linux-gnu WARNING: IPv6 is not supported yet.

docs.title: connect_to_tcp_server : Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket
docs.text: Connects to a remote TCP server as a client. The first argument is {host}:{port}, where {host} is an IP Address (eg. 192.168.0.1), or a FQDN host name (eg. www.example.com), and {port} is a port number (eg. 8080). If the port number is omitted, the default port number is 80.

docs.title: listen_tcp_server : Std::String -> Std::I64 -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket
docs.text:
Listens at the specified address as a server.

The first argument is {host}:{port}, where {host} is an IP Address (typically, 127.0.0.1), or a FQDN host name (typically, localhost), and {port} is a port number (eg. 8080). If the port number is omitted, the default port number is 80.

The second argument (backlog) is the maximum length to which the queue of pending connections for the socket may grow.

docs.title: flush : Minilib.Net.Tcp::BufferedSocket -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::BufferedSocket
docs.text: Sends the contents of the writer buffer to the socket and cleans the write buffer.

docs.title: make : Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::BufferedSocket
docs.text: Makes a BufferedSocket from a Socket.

docs.title: read_line : Minilib.Net.Tcp::BufferedSocket -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::String, Minilib.Net.Tcp::BufferedSocket)
docs.text: Reads out a line (ie. a string that ends with a newline) from the read buffer. When the read buffer does not contain a newline, it will read some bytes upto _BUFSIZE from the socket, and search for a newline again. When the connection is closed, the return value may or may not contain a newline. The next call of read_line() returns an empty string, which represents that the connection is closed.

docs.title: write_str : Std::String -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::BufferedSocket -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::BufferedSocket
docs.text: Writes a string to the write buffer. The contents of the write buffer is not sent until the size of the write buffer is equal to or greater than _BUFSIZE, or flush() is called.

docs.title: from_U32 : Std::U32 -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::IpAddress
docs.text: Converts U32 to an IpAddress, for example 0x7f000001_U32 -> 127.0.0.1.

docs.title: from_array : Std::Array Std::U8 -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::IpAddress
docs.text: Converts a byte array to an IpAddress. The length of the byte array must be 4.

docs.title: resolve : Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::IpAddress
docs.text: Resolve a hostname such as "127.0.0.1" or "www.example.com".

docs.title: _unsafe_from_fd : Std::FFI::CInt -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket
docs.text: Creates Socket from a file descriptor of a socket. The socket will be automatically closed when Socket is deallocated.

docs.title: accept : Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO::IOFail (Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket, Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress)
docs.text: Waits for an incoming connection request. If an incoming connection arrives, accept it, and returns a socket of accepted connection and the remote socket address.

docs.title: accept_fd : Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::FFI::CInt, Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress)
docs.text: Same as accept(), except that it returns the accepted socket's file descriptor instead of Socket.

docs.title: bind : Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Assigns an IPv4 ip address and a port number to the socket.

docs.title: borrow_fd_io : (Std::FFI::CInt -> Std::IO a) -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Call an IO action with a file descriptor of a socket.

docs.title: connect : Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Connects to the specified address.

docs.title: listen : Std::I64 -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Listens the socket for incoming connection requests. The first argument (backlog) is the maximum length to which the queue of pending connections for sockfd may grow.

docs.title: make_tcp_socket : () -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket
docs.text: Creates new tcp socket. The socket will be automatically closed when Socket is deallocated.

docs.title: recv : Std::I64 -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::Array Std::U8)
docs.text: Receives messages from a socket. The first argument is the maximum number of bytes to receive. If no message are available at the socket, recv() waits for a message to arrive. Returns the number of bytes received. When the socket has been shutdown, the return value will be 0.

docs.title: send : Std::Array Std::U8 -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Socket -> Std::IO::IOFail Std::I64
docs.text: Transmits a message to another socket. May be used only when the socket is in a connected state. Returns the number of bytes sent.

docs.title: _unsafe_from_sockaddr_in : Std::Ptr -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress
docs.text: Creates a SocketAddress from an allocated pointer to struct sockaddr_in.

docs.title: get_ipaddress : Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::IpAddress
docs.text: Extracts an ip address from the socket address.

docs.title: get_port : Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Port
docs.text: Extracts a port number from the socket address.

docs.title: make : Minilib.Net.Tcp::IpAddress -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::Port -> Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress
docs.text: Creates a SocketAddress from an ip address and a port.

docs.title: resolve : Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail Minilib.Net.Tcp::SocketAddress::SocketAddress
docs.text:
Splits the first argument into a host name and a port number, then resolves the host name to an ip address, then creates a SocketAddress from the ip address and the port number.

The first argument is {host}:{port}, where {host} is an IP Address (eg. 192.168.0.1), or a FQDN host name (eg. www.example.com), and {port} is a port number (eg. 8080). If the port number is omitted, the default port number is 80.

docs.title: type BufferedSocket = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: This type is a structure that wraps a Socket and maintains a write buffer, a read buffer and an EOF flag.

docs.title: type IpAddress = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: This type represents IPv4 ip address, eg. 127.0.0.1, 192.168.0.1 etc.

docs.title: type Port = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: This type reprents IPv4 port number, 0-65535.

docs.title: type Socket = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: This type represents an IPv4 socket. It consists of a socket file descriptor. The socket file descripter is closed automatically when Socket is deallocated.

docs.title: type SocketAddress = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: This type represents IPv4 ip address and port number.

docs.title: parse : Std::String -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg Minilib.Net.URL::URL
docs.text: Parses a string as a URL. Recognized format of a URL is: [scheme://]host[:port][path] If the scheme part is omitted, a default value ("http") is used as a scheme. The host and port part should not contain "/". If the port part is omitted, a default value ("443" if scheme == "https", "80" otherwise) is used as a port. The path part should be starts with "/". If the path part is omitted, a default value ("/") is used as a path.

docs.title: Minilib.Testing.UnitTest
docs.text: Unit Test Framework

docs.title: _TEST_VERBOSE : Std::Bool
docs.text:
If _TEST_VERBOSE is true, the results of all testcases will be printed. If _TEST_VERBOSE is false, the results of only failed testcases will be printed.

If the environment variable TEST_VERBOSE is set to non-empty string, _TEST_VERBOSE becomes true. For example, running the TEST_VERBOSE=1 fix test command at a shell prompt will report all testcases.

docs.title: assert_equal : [a : Std::Eq, a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> a -> a -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Verifies that two values are equal. If the values are different, the test will fail with the specified message.

docs.title: assert_not_equal : [a : Std::Eq, a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> a -> a -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Verifies that two values are not equal. If the values are equal, the test will fail with the specified message.

docs.title: assert_true : Std::String -> Std::Bool -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Verifies that the boolean value is true. If the boolean value is false, the test will fail with the specified message.

docs.title: make_table_test : [a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> Std::Array a -> (a -> Std::IO::IOFail ()) -> Minilib.Testing.UnitTest::TestCase
docs.text: Creates a set of test cases from parameters and a lazy IOFail ().

docs.title: make_test : Std::String -> Std::Lazy (Std::IO::IOFail ()) -> Minilib.Testing.UnitTest::TestCase
docs.text: Creates a named test case from a lazy IOFail ().

docs.title: run_test_driver : Std::Array Minilib.Testing.UnitTest::TestCase -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: Executes all test cases. This function: - Sets stdout and stderr to be unbuffered for immediate output. - Runs all test cases. - Prints a summary of the results, including the number of passed and failed tests. - If any test case fails or an error occurs, prints the error message and aborts the program. - If all test cases passed, returns pure().

docs.title: run_tests : Std::Array Minilib.Testing.UnitTest::TestCase -> Minilib.Testing.UnitTest::TestCase
docs.text: Executes all test cases and treat the results as one test case.

docs.title: empty : Minilib.Testing.UnitTest::TestCase
docs.text: A test case where the number of successes and number of failures are both equal to 0. Can be used as a placeholder at the end of an array of test cases.

docs.title: type TestCase = Std::Lazy (Std::IO::IOFail (Std::I64, Std::I64))
docs.text: TestCase is a type that counts the number of successful and failed tests.

docs.title: encode_hex_char : Std::U8 -> Std::U8
docs.text: Converts a 4bit number (0..15) to a hex character ('0'..'9', 'a'..'f').

docs.title: impl Std::Array Std::U8 : Minilib.Text.Hex::FromStringHex
docs.text: Converts a byte array from a hex string. For example, "a5b6".from_string_hex == ok $ [ 0xa5_U8, 0xb6_U8 ]. Whitespaces are ignored.

docs.title: impl [a : Minilib.Text.Hex::ToStringHex] Std::Array a : Minilib.Text.Hex::ToStringHex

docs.title: impl Std::U32 : Minilib.Text.Hex::ToStringHex

docs.title: impl Std::U64 : Minilib.Text.Hex::FromStringHex
docs.text: Converts a hex string of 1..16 characters to U64.

docs.title: impl Std::U64 : Minilib.Text.Hex::ToStringHex

docs.title: impl Std::U8 : Minilib.Text.Hex::ToStringHex

docs.text: Returns the current stream position.

docs.title: if_exists : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser (Std::Option a)
docs.text: p.if_exists returns some(x) if p returns x as a parse result, or none() if p does not match.

docs.title: map_result : (a -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg b) -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser b
docs.text: parser.map_result(f) maps the parser result with f, possibly reports an error message.

docs.title: match_any_char : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Char
docs.text: Matches any single character. The parsed result is a single matched character. If the match fails (eg. the end of stream), a _NotMatch error is raised.

docs.title: match_char : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Char -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser ()
docs.text: Matches a single character specified by the argument. The parsed result is nothing. If the match fails, a _NotMatch error is raised.

docs.title: match_char_class : (Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Char -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Char
docs.text: Matches a character satisfying the specified condition.

docs.title: match_char_if_exists : Std::U8 -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser (Std::Option Std::U8)
docs.text: Matches a single character if it exists. The parsed result is some(c) if it exists, none() if it does not exist.

docs.title: match_empty_str : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::String
docs.text: Matches a zero-length string.

docs.title: match_end_of_stream : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser ()
docs.text: Matches zero-length string at the end of stream.

docs.title: match_integer : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::I64
docs.text: Matches an integer.

docs.title: match_one_of_char : Std::String -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::String
docs.text: Matches a character which is included in the specified string. The parsed result is a string consisting of the single matched character. If the match fails, a _NotMatch error is raised.

docs.title: match_str : Std::String -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser ()
docs.text: Matches a string specified by the argument. The parsed result is nothing. If the match fails, a _NotMatch error is raised.

docs.title: match_str_class : (Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Char -> Std::Bool) -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::String
docs.text: Matches a zero-or-more-length string. Each character should satisfy the specified condition.

docs.title: match_str_class_digit : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::String
docs.text: Matches a zero-or-more-length string of digit characters.

docs.title: match_str_class_lower : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::String
docs.text: Matches a zero-or-more-length string of lowercase characters.

docs.title: match_str_class_whitespace : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser Std::String
docs.text: Matches a zero-or-more-length string of whitespace characters.

docs.title: not_match : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a
docs.text: Raises a _NotMatch error.

docs.title: one_or_more : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser (Std::Array a)
docs.text: Same as zero_or_more, but raises a _NotMatch error if the array length is zero.

docs.title: or_else : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a
docs.text: If the first Parser raises a _NotMatch error, tries the second Parser. Note that pa1.or_else(pa2) is interpreted as or_else(pa2, pa1), and that pa1.or_else $ pa2 is interpreted as or_else(pa1, pa2).

docs.title: or_elseF : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a
docs.text: Flipped version of or_else. pa1.or_elseF $ pa2 is equivalent to pa1.or_else(pa2).

docs.title: or_error : Std::String -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a
docs.text: If the Parser reports any error (including _NotMatch), raises the specified string as an error.

docs.title: repeat : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser (Std::Array a)
docs.text: Repeats matches as many as possible. The parse result is an array of successful matches. If a _NotMatch error is raised, returns as success. If an error other than _NotMatch is raised, reports that error.

docs.title: run_parser : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::ParseResult a
docs.text: Apply a stream to a parsing function and return the parsed result.

docs.title: run_parser_str : Std::String -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::ParseResult a
docs.text: Create a stream from a string, then apply a stream to a parsing function and return the parsed result.

docs.title: unit : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser ()
docs.text: Match zero-length string.

docs.title: zero_or_more : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser a -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Parser (Std::Array a)
docs.text: Synonym for repeat.

docs.title: advance : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream -> Std::Option (Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Char, Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream)
docs.text: stream.advance gets next character and increment the stream position.

docs.title: empty : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream
docs.text: An empty Stream.

docs.title: error : Std::String -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg a
docs.text: stream.error(str) reports an error along with where it occurred.

docs.title: make : Std::String -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream
docs.text: Creates a stream from specified string.

docs.title: read_all : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream -> (Std::Array Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Char, Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream)
docs.text: stream.read_all reads all characters to the end of stream.

docs.title: read_string : Std::I64 -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream -> Std::String
docs.text: stream.read_string(n) reads at most n characters and convert them to a string.

docs.title: read_string_between : Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream -> Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream -> Std::String
docs.text: start_stream.read_string_between(end_stream) reads characters from start_stream to end_stream and convert them to a string.

docs.title: type Char = Std::U8
docs.text: The type of characters. Currently only UTF-8 string is supported.

docs.title: type ParseResult = Std::Result Std::ErrMsg (a, Minilib.Text.SimpleParser::Stream::Stream)
docs.text: Result type that returns a value of an arbitrary type and a stream.

docs.title: type Parser a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: A structure with a function that receive a stream, parse it, and return the parsed result and the next stream position.

docs.title: type Stream = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: A character iterator that stores the file name, line number, column number, and offset from the beginning of the file.

docs.text: Creates a stream from a string.

docs.title: Minilib.Text.StringEx
docs.text:
String utility functions.

Features: - Array U8 -> String conversion - Search, replace, split, comparison of String - Format

docs.title: _append_range : Std::Array a -> Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text: (Internal function)

docs.title: _unsafe_to_string : Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::String
docs.text:
Converts a byte array to a string. Specifically, it calls String::_unsafe_to_string() after appending a null character to the end of the byte array.

Example:

[ 'a', 'b', 'c' ]._unsafe_to_string
==> "abc"
[ 0x41_U8, 0x42_U8, 0x43_U8 ]._unsafe_to_string
==> "ABC"

docs.title: byte_to_string : Std::U8 -> Std::String
docs.text:
Deprecated: Please use Std::String::from_U8.

Converts a byte (a character) to a string of length 1.

Example:

0x41_U8.byte_to_string
==> "A"

docs.title: ends_with : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::Bool
docs.text:
Checks if a string ends with the specified suffix.

Example:

"/foo/bar.txt".ends_with(".txt")
==> true
"foo/bar.txt".ends_with(".bin")
==> false

docs.title: find_byte : Std::U8 -> Std::String -> Std::Option Std::I64
docs.text:
Searches for the specified byte from the beginning of a string. If found, returns the index of that byte.

Example:

"aaa/bbb/ccc".find_byte('/')
==> some(3)
"aaa".find_byte('/')
==> none()

docs.title: find_last_byte : Std::U8 -> Std::String -> Std::Option Std::I64
docs.text:
Searches for the specified byte from the end of a string. If found, returns the index of that byte.

Example:

"aaa/bbb/ccc".find_last_byte('/')
==> some(7)
"aaa".find_last_byte('/')
==> none()

docs.title: formatv : Std::String -> Std::Array Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text:
array.formatv(str) replaces each occurence of {} in the format string str with each element of array. Currently only supports {}.

Example:

["1", "2", "3"].formatv("foo={} bar={} baz={}")
==> "foo=1 bar=2 baz=3"
["1"].formatv("foo={} bar={} baz={}")
==> "foo=1 bar={} baz={}"

docs.title: replace_all : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text:
input.replace_all(from, to) replaces all occurrences of from in the input string with to. If from is empty, returns the input string unchanged.

Example:

"foo1:11,foo2:22,Foo3:33".replace_all("foo", "piyo")
==> "piyo1:11,piyo2:22,Foo3:33"
"foo1:11,foo2:22,Foo3:33".replace_all("foo", "")
==> "1:11,2:22,Foo3:33"
"foo1:11,foo2:22,Foo3:33".replace_all("", "piyo")
==> "foo1:11,foo2:22,Foo3:33"

docs.title: replace_suffix : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg Std::String
docs.text:
str.replace_suffix(from, to) replaces from at the end of str with to. if str does not end with from, an error occurs.

Example:

"test.txt".replace_suffix(".txt", ".tmp")
 ==> ok("test.tmp")
"test.jpg".replace_suffix(".txt", ".tmp")
 ==> err("suffix does not match: test.jpg")

docs.title: split_by : (Std::U8 -> Std::Bool) -> Std::String -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator Std::String
docs.text:
Splits a string by a function that checks whether a character is a delimiter or not. The result will not contain any empty string.

Example:

"  aa bb  12 ".split_by(Character::is_space).to_array
==>  ["aa", "bb", "12"]

docs.title: split_ex : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator Std::String
docs.text:
Deprecated: Please use Std::String::split.

Same as Std::String::split, except that "foo".split_ex(",") returns a singleton iterator of "foo".

Example:

"foo,bar,baz".split_ex(",").to_array
==> ["foo", "bar", "baz"]
"foo".split_ex(",").to_array
==> ["foo"]

docs.title: split_first : Std::String -> Std::String -> (Std::String, Std::String)
docs.text:
str.split_first(delim) splits the string str into two parts at the first occurence of the delimiter delim. Returns (left, right) where left is the left part of the delimiter, and right is the right part of the delimiter. Returns (str, "") if the delimiter is not found.

Example:

"aaa/bbb/ccc".split_first("/")
==> ("aaa", "bbb/ccc")
"aaa/bbb/ccc".split_first("bb")
==> ("aaa/", "b/ccc")
"aaa/bbb/ccc".split_first("!")
==> ("aaa/bbb/ccc", "")

docs.title: starts_with : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::Bool
docs.text:
Checks if a string starts with the specified prefix.

Example:

"/foo/bar.txt".starts_with("/")
==> true
"foo/bar.txt".starts_with("/")
==> false

docs.title: subarray : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text:
Deprecated: Please use Std::Array::get_sub.

Returns a subarray extracted from a specified range from an array. If the specified range exceeds the array, it will be truncated to fit within the array.

Example:

[10, 11, 12, 13, 14].subarray(1, 2)
==> [11, 12]
[10, 11, 12, 13, 14].subarray(0, 5)
==> [10, 11, 12, 13, 14]
[10, 11, 12, 13, 14].subarray(-1, 6)
==> [10, 11, 12, 13, 14]

docs.title: substring : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text:
Deprecated: Please use Std::String::get_sub.

Returns a substring extracted from a specified range from a string. If the specified range exceeds the string, it will be truncated to fit within the string.

Example:

"abcdef".substring(2, 3)
==> "cde"
"abcdef".substring(0, 6)
==> "abcdef"
"abcdef".substring(-1, 7)
==> "abcdef"

docs.title: to_lower : Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text:
Converts the specified string to lowercase.

Example:

"ABCdef123".to_lower
==> "abcdef123"

docs.title: to_upper : Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text:
Converts the specified string to uppercase.

Example:

"ABCdef123".to_upper
==> "ABCDEF123"

docs.title: format : [a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> Std::Array a -> Std::String
docs.text:
array.format(str) replaces each occurence of {} in the format string str with each element of array. Currently only supports {}.

Example:

[some(1), some(2), none()].format("foo={} bar={} baz={}")
==> "foo=some(1) bar=some(2) baz=none()"
[some(1)].format("foo={} bar={} baz={}")
==> "foo=some(1) bar={} baz={}"

docs.title: format : [a : Std::ToString] Std::String -> (a,) -> Std::String
docs.text:
(a, ).format(str) replaces an occurence of {} in the format string str with a.

Example:

(12.345, ).format("float={}")
==> "float=12.345000"
([1, 2, 3], ).format("arr={}")
==> "arr=[1, 2, 3]"

docs.title: format : [a : Std::ToString, b : Std::ToString] Std::String -> (a, b) -> Std::String
docs.text:
(a, b).format(str) replaces each occurence of {} in the format string str with a, b.

Example:

(12, "abc").format("int={} str={}")
==> "int=12 str=abc"

docs.title: format : [a : Std::ToString, b : Std::ToString, c : Std::ToString] Std::String -> (a, b, c) -> Std::String
docs.text:
(a, b, c).format(str) replaces each occurence of {} in the format string str with a, b, c.

Example:

(12, 345.678, "abc").format("int={} float={} str={}")
==> "int=12 float=345.678000 str=abc"

docs.title: format : [a : Std::ToString, b : Std::ToString, c : Std::ToString, d : Std::ToString] Std::String -> (a, b, c, d) -> Std::String
docs.text:
(a, b, c, d).format(str) replaces each occurence of {} in the format string str with a, b, c, d.

Example:

(12, 345.678, "abc", some(1)).format("int={} float={} str={} option={}")
==> "int=12 float=345.678000 str=abc option=some(1)"

docs.title: format : [a : Std::ToString, b : Std::ToString, c : Std::ToString, d : Std::ToString, e : Std::ToString] Std::String -> (a, b, c, d, e) -> Std::String
docs.text:
(a, b, c, d, e).format(str) replaces each occurence of {} in the format string str with a, b, c, d, e.

Example:

(12, 345.678, "abc", some(1), [1, 2, 3]).format("int={} float={} str={} option={} array={}")
==> "int=12 float=345.678000 str=abc option=some(1) array=[1, 2, 3]"

docs.title: Minilib.Thread.Channel
docs.text: A Channel that can be used for the communication of threads.

docs.title: clear : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: channel.clear clears the queue of the channel.

docs.title: close : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: channel.close closes a channel. After close, send() will fail.

docs.title: closed_error : Std::ErrMsg
docs.text: An error message which is reported when the channel is closed.

docs.title: is_closed : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO Std::Bool
docs.text: channel.is_closed checks whether the channel is closed.

docs.title: is_empty : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO Std::Bool
docs.text: channel.is_empty checks whether the queue of the channel is empty.

docs.title: make : Std::IO (Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a)
docs.text: Channel::make creates a new channel.

docs.title: recv : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO::IOFail a
docs.text: channel.recv receives a data from the queue of the channel. If the queue is empty, it waits until any data is sent, or the channel is closed. If the channel is closed and the queue is empty, it throws closed_error.

docs.title: send : a -> Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: channel.send(a) sends a data to the queue of the channel. If the channel is closed, it throws closed_error.

docs.title: take_and_clear : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO (Std::Iterator::DynIterator a)
docs.text: channel.take_and_clear takes all items away from the queue of the channel and clears the queue. This function can be used after the channel is closed.

docs.title: try_recv : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel a -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::Option a)
docs.text: channel.recv tries to receive a data from a channel. If there is no data, none is returned. If the channel is closed and the queue is empty, it throws closed_error.

docs.title: Minilib.Thread.TaskPool
docs.text:
A task pool that can be used parallel computation.

A task pool creates IOTasks and starts them. Each task waits for request until shutdown. When the task receives the request, it performs the request as a computation. When the task pool is shutdown, all tasks are stopped. Computations are never performed after shutdown.

docs.title: _task_func : Minilib.Thread.Channel::Channel Minilib.Thread.Future::FutureToken -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: The task function of the taskpool.

docs.title: cancel_all_pendings_futures : Minilib.Thread.TaskPool::TaskPool -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: Cancel all pending futures and clears the queue.

docs.title: is_shutdown : Minilib.Thread.TaskPool::TaskPool -> Std::IO Std::Bool
docs.text: Checks whether the taskpool has been shutdown.

docs.title: make : Std::I64 -> Std::IO Minilib.Thread.TaskPool::TaskPool
docs.text: TaskPool::make(task_count) creates a TaskPool.

docs.title: register_future : Minilib.Thread.Future::FutureToken -> Minilib.Thread.TaskPool::TaskPool -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Register a future. It sends a future token to the channel.

docs.title: shutdown : Minilib.Thread.TaskPool::TaskPool -> Std::IO Minilib.Thread.TaskPool::TaskPool
docs.text: Shutdowns a taskpool.

docs.title: type TaskPool = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: A task pool that manages a collection of IOTasks.
