docs.title: lens_rng : [rg : Minilib.Trait.Rng::Rng, rg2 : Minilib.Trait.Rng::Rng, f : Std::Functor, Minilib.Trait.Rng::Rng::RngResult rg a = f a] ((rg -> Minilib.Functor.Pair::PairLT a f rg) -> rg2 -> Minilib.Functor.Pair::PairLT a f rg2) -> (rg -> f (rg, a)) -> rg2 -> f (rg2, a)
docs.text: Converts a rng_xxx function using a lens action. Useful for implementing the Rng trait for containers that have a member implementing the Rng trait. For instance, rng_U64.lens_rng(act_random) creates an rng_U64 function that performs the act_random action. Refer to the Container type in monad_random_test.fix for a detailed example. Note that this function is similar to State::lens_state_t.

docs.title: associated type RngResult rg a
docs.text: The result type of rng_xxx functions. This should be a monad, for example Identity a, IOFail a etc. This result will be lifted by the lifter.

docs.title: associated type [m : *->*] RngLift rg m a
docs.text: A lifter that lifts RngResult into a desired monad. Requirements: - Implements the Lifter trait. - LiftFrom type must be RngResult rg a. - LiftTo type must be m a. Typically, this type is set to LifterImpl (n a) (m a) where n a = RngResult rg a.

docs.title: Minilib.Trait.Semigroup
docs.text:
Semigroup trait and its several implementations (Array, Iterator, String etc).

Semigroup has an associative binary operation, namely sappend. It may or may not have an identity.

For details, see Wikipedia: Semigroup.

docs.text: a.sappend(b) appends b after a.

docs.text: a.sappend(b) appends b after a.

docs.text: () does not change with sappend.

docs.title: impl Std::Array a : Minilib.Trait.Semigroup::Semigroup

docs.title: impl Std::String : Minilib.Trait.Semigroup::Semigroup

docs.title: foreach_m : [m : Std::Monad, t : Minilib.Trait.Traversable::Traversable, t : Std::Functor] (a -> m ()) -> t a -> m ()
docs.text:
ta.foreach_m(f) maps each element with f, then performs all elements sequentially and forgets the results. Similar to Haskell's mapM function, but the results are discarded.

Example:

["hello", "world"].foreach_m(println);;
==> ("hello\nworld\n" is printed)

docs.title: map_m : [m : Std::Monad, t : Minilib.Trait.Traversable::Traversable, t : Std::Functor] (a -> m b) -> t a -> m (t b)
docs.text:
ta.map_m(f) maps each element with f, then performs all elements sequentially and collects the results. Similar to Haskell's mapM function.

Example:

let ios = ...Array of IO operations...;
let tasks = *ios.map_m(AsyncIOTask::make);
let results = *tasks.map_m(get);
==> (tasks are created and started in parallel, then the results of tasks are collected)

docs.title: traverse : [m : Std::Monad, t : Minilib.Trait.Traversable::Traversable, t : Std::Functor] (a -> m b) -> t a -> m (t b)
docs.text: ta.traverse(f) maps each element with f, then performs all elements sequentially and collects the results. traverse is a synonym of map_m.

docs.title: sequence : [t : Minilib.Trait.Traversable::Traversable, m : Std::Monad] t (m a) -> m (t a)
docs.text: ta.sequence performs all elements sequentially and collects the results. Similar to Haskell's sequence function.

docs.text: A trait for types which can traverse all elements with Monad.

docs.title: method sequence : [m : Std::Monad] t (m a) -> m (t a)
docs.text: ta.sequence performs all elements sequentially and collects the results. Similar to Haskell's sequence function.

docs.title: type NFAFrag = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text:
NFA Fragment

NFA Fragment is a collection of nodes. It exports one input, And a function to set the output. Internally, the output of a fragment is a collection of outputs of one or more nodes. Calling set_output() will change them all.

docs.title: type NFANode = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text:
NFA node

NFA node has one input (ID of this node) and three outputs (one output guarded by the action, and two outputs with no guard).

docs.title: type NFANodeAction = unbox union { ...variants... }
docs.text: Actions that has to be performed before the state makes a transition to node.@out_on_action.

docs.text: NFA state set, used for NFA state transition

docs.title: type NodeID = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: ID of NFA node. -1 is invalid value.

docs.title: type QuantID = Std::I64
docs.text: Type of special quantifiers ID. Special quantifiers are quantifieres other than X? X* X+. In other words, they are X{n} X{n,} X{n,m} etc. Special quantifiers are hard to implement only using node transition, so its iteration count are stored in the NFA state, and managed by sa_quant_* actions.

docs.title: type ReplaceFrag = unbox union { ...variants... }
docs.text: A replacement fragment

docs.title: RegExp
docs.text:
Simple regular expression.

Currently it only supports patterns below: - Character classes: [xyz], [^xyz], ., \d, \D, \w, \W, \s, \S, \t, \r, \n, \v, \f, [\b], x|y - Assertions: ^, $ - Groups: (x) - Quantifiers: x*, x+, x?, x{n}, x{n,}, x{n,m}

For details, see mdn web docs: Regular expressions.

LIMITATION:

Currently, only single byte characters (U+0001..U+007F) can be specified in character classes. Non-ASCII characters (U+0080..U+10FFFF) are encoded to two or more bytes in UTF-8, so they cannot be specified in character classes. And the null character (U+0000) cannot be used in Fix strings.

docs.title: compile : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg RegExp::RegExp
docs.text: RegExp::compile(pattern, flags) compiles pattern into a regular expression. flags change behavior of regular expression matching. Currently only global flag ("g") is supported.

docs.title: match_all : Std::String -> RegExp::RegExp -> Std::Array (Std::Array Std::String)
docs.text:
regexp.match_all(target) matches target against regexp. All matching results will be returned including captured groups.

If the match against the regular expression fails, an empty array is returned.

This function is similar to String.matchAll() function of JavaScript.

docs.title: match_one : Std::String -> RegExp::RegExp -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg (Std::Array Std::String)
docs.text:
regexp.match(target) matches target against regexp.

If the global flag ("g") is not set, it returns an array of the groups of the first match. Group 0 is a substring that matches the entire regular expression. Group 1 and beyond are the captured substrings in each group. If not captured, the group will be an empty string.

Example:

let regexp = RegExp::compile("[a-z]+([0-9]+)", "").as_ok;
let groups = regexp.match_one("abc012 def345").as_ok;
// groups == ["abc012", "012"]

If the global flag ("g") is set, all matching results will be returned, but captured groups will not be included.

Example:

let regexp = RegExp::compile("[a-z]+([0-9]+)", "g").as_ok;
let groups = regexp.match_one("abc012 def345").as_ok;
// groups == ["abc012", "def345"]

If the match against the regular expression fails, an error "NotMatch" is reported.

This function is similar to String.match() function of JavaScript.

docs.title: replace_all : Std::String -> Std::String -> RegExp::RegExp -> Std::String
docs.text:
regexp.replace_all(target, replacement) matches target against regexp, and replace all matching substrings with replacement. If replacement contains $&, it is substituted with entire matched substring. If replacement contains $n where n is an integer, it is substituted with the captured group. If replacement contains $$, it is substituted with single $.

Example:

let regexp = RegExp::compile("(\\w\\w)(\\w)", "").as_ok;
let result = regexp.replace_all("abc def ijk", "$2$1");
// result == "cab fde kij"

This function is similar to String.replaceAll() function of JavaScript. Note that $', $`, $<Name> are not supported yet.

docs.title: type RegExp = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: Type of a compiled regular expression.

docs.title: Std
docs.text:
Module Std provides basic types, traits and values.

This module is special in the sense that: - It is always imported implicitly. If you don't want to import some or all of entities in this module, you should write import Std {...entities...} explicitly. - It contains built-in types or values which are defined or implemented directly by Fix compiler, not by Fix source code.

NOTE on tuples: The tuple types Std::TupleN are defined on demand, i.e., if the user uses N-tuple in the source code, the compiler generates definition TupleN and related functions / trait implementations. The document for Std module describes about them up to N=3, but you can use larger tuples in the same way.

docs.title: compose : (a -> b) -> (b -> c) -> a -> c
docs.text: Composes two functions. Composition operators << and >> is translated to use of compose.

docs.title: fix : ((a -> b) -> a -> b) -> a -> b
docs.text:
fix enables you to make a recursive function locally.

The idiom is fix $ |loop, arg| -> {loop_body}. In {loop_body}, you can call loop to make a recursion.

Example:

module Main;

main : IO ();
main = (
    let fact = fix $ |loop, n| if n == 0 { 1 } else { n * loop (n-1) };
    println $ fact(5).to_string // evaluates to 5 * 4 * 3 * 2 * 1 = 120
);

docs.title: loop : s -> (s -> Std::LoopState s r) -> r
docs.text:
loop enables you to make a loop. LoopState is a union type defined as follows:

type LoopState s r = unbox union { continue : s, break : r };

loop takes two arguments: the initial state of the loop s0 and the loop body function body. It first calls body on s0. If body returns break(r), then the loop ends and returns r as the result. If body returns continue(s), then the loop calls again body on s.

Example:

module Main;

main : IO ();
main = (
    let sum = loop((0, 0), |(i, sum)|
        if i == 100 { break $ sum };
        continue $ (i + 1, sum + i)
    );
    println $ sum.to_string
); // evaluates to 0 + 1 + ... + 99

docs.title: loop_m : [m : Std::Monad] s -> (s -> m (Std::LoopState s r)) -> m r
docs.text:
Monadic loop function. This is similar to loop but can be used to perform monadic action at each loop.

It is convenient to use continue_m and break_m to create monadic loop body function.

The following program prints "Hello World! (i)" for i = 0, 1, 2.

module Main;

main : IO ();
main = (
    loop_m(0, |i| (
        if i == 3 { break_m $ () };
        println("Hello World! (" + i.to_string + ")");;
        continue_m $ i + 1
    ))
);

docs.title: mark_threaded : a -> a
docs.text: Traverses all values reachable from the given value, and changes the reference counters of them into multi-threaded mode.

docs.title: undefined : Std::String -> a
docs.text:
Generates an undefined value.

Calling this function prints msg to the stderr, flush stderr, and aborts the program (calls abort in libc). Since undefined(msg) has generic type a, you can put it anywhere and it will be type-checked.

This is useful when you want to write a placeholder that will be implemented later:

truth : I64;
truth = undefined("I will implement the truth later.");

Another use case is aborting the program when a certain branch of the code should not be reached:

if condition {
    // Do something.
} else {
    undefined("This branch should not be reached.");
}

docs.title: unsafe_is_unique : a -> (Std::Bool, a)
docs.text:
This function checks if a value is uniquely referenced by a name, and returns the result paired with the given value itself. An unboxed value is always considered unique.

NOTE: Changing outputs of your function depending on uniqueness breaks the referential transparency of the function. If you want to assert that a value is unique, consider using Debug::assert_unique instead.

Example: 

module Main;


main : IO ();
main = (
    // For unboxed value, it returns true even if the value is used later.
    let int_val = 42;
    let (unique, _) = int_val.unsafe_is_unique;
    let use = int_val + 1;
    assert_eq(|_|"fail: int_val is shared", unique, true);;

    // For boxed value, it returns true if the value isn't used later.
    let arr = Array::fill(10, 10);
    let (unique, arr) = arr.unsafe_is_unique;
    let use = arr.@(0); // This `arr` is not the one passed to `is_unique`, but the one returned by `is_unique`.
    assert_eq(|_|"fail: arr is shared", unique, true);;

    // Fox boxed value, it returns false if the value will be used later.
    let arr = Array::fill(10, 10);
    let (unique, _) = arr.unsafe_is_unique;
    let use = arr.@(0);
    assert_eq(|_|"fail: arr is unique", unique, false);;

    pure()
);

docs.title: with_retained : (a -> b) -> a -> b
docs.text:
x.with_retained(f) runs f with retained x. It is guaranteed that x is keep alive until with_retained is finished, even after f has finished using x in it.

A typical use case of this function is the implementation of Std::Array::borrow_ptr.

docs.title: add : [a : Std::Add] a -> a -> a

docs.title: @ : Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> a
docs.text: Gets an element of an array at the specified index.

docs.title: _get_ptr : Std::Array a -> Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Get the pointer to the memory region where elements are stored.

This function is dangerous because if the array is not used after call of this function, the array will be deallocated soon and the returned pointer will be dangling. Try using borrow_ptr instead.

@deprecated Use Std::FFI::_get_boxed_ptr instead.

docs.title: _get_sub_size_with_length_and_additional_capacity : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text: A function like get_sub, but behaves as if the size of the array is the specified value, and has a parameter to specify additional capacity of the returned Array.

docs.title: _sort_range_using_buffer : Std::Array a -> Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> ((a, a) -> Std::Bool) -> Std::Array a -> (Std::Array a, Std::Array a)
docs.text:
Sorts elements in a range of a vector by "less than" comparator.

This function receives a working buffer as the first argument to reduce memory allocation, and returns it as second element.

docs.title: _unsafe_force_unique : Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text:
Force the uniqueness of an array. If the given array is shared, this function returns the cloned array.

DEPRECATED: This function is unsafe and deprecated because it is fragile when the "common expression elimination" optimization is implemented in the future. Consider the following example:

f : Array a -> Array a
f = |arr| arr.force_unique.do_something_for_unique_array;

let x = [1, 2, 3];
let y = f(x);
let z = f(x);

When this function f is inlined, the code will be as follows.

let x = [1, 2, 3];
let y = x.force_unique.do_something_for_unique_array;
let z = x.force_unique.do_something_for_unique_array;

Here, if the optimization is applied to the two x.force_unique, the code will call do_something_for_unique_array with a non-unique array.

let x = [1, 2, 3];
let x = x.force_unique;
let y = x.do_something_for_unique_array; // Here `x` is not unique
let z = x.do_something_for_unique_array;

Therefore, to use this function safely, you need to suppress the inlining of the above f. It is uncertain whether a function attribute such as "noinline" will be added in the future, so this function is deprecated currently.

docs.title: _unsafe_get : Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> a
docs.text: Gets a value from an array and returns it paired with the array itself, without bounds checking and retaining the value.

docs.title: _unsafe_get_linear : Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> (Std::Array a, a)
docs.text: Gets a value from an array, without bounds checking and retaining the returned value.

docs.title: _unsafe_set : Std::I64 -> a -> Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text: Sets a value into an array, without uniqueness checking, bounds checking and releasing the old value.

docs.title: _unsafe_set_size : Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text: Updates the length of an array, without uniqueness checking or validation of the given length value.

docs.title: act : [f : Std::Functor] Std::I64 -> (a -> f a) -> Std::Array a -> f (Std::Array a)
docs.text:
Modifies an array by a functorial action.

Semantically, arr.act(idx, fun) is equivalent to fun(arr.@(idx)).map(|elm| arr.set(idx, elm)).

This function can be defined for any functor f in general, but it is easier to understand the behavior when f is a monad: the monadic action act(idx, fun, arr) first performs fun(arr.@(idx)) to get a value elm, and returns a pure value arr.set(idx, elm).

If you call arr.act(idx, fun) when both of arr and arr.@(idx) are unique, it is assured that fun receives the unique value.

If you call act on an array which is shared, this function clones the given array when inserting the result of your action into the array. This means that you don't need to pay cloning cost when your action failed, as expected.

docs.title: append : Std::Array a -> Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text:
Appends an array to an array.

Note: Since a1.append(a2) puts a2 after a1, append(lhs, rhs) puts lhs after rhs.

The capacity is set to the same value as the length.

Example: fill(n, x) == [x, x, x, ..., x] (of length n).

docs.title: mod : Std::I64 -> (a -> a) -> Std::Array a -> Std::Array a
docs.text:
Updates an array by applying a function to the element at the specified index.

This function clones the given array if it is shared.

If you call arr.mod(i, f) when both of arr and arr.@(i) are unique, it is assured that f receives the element value which is unique.

truncante(len, arr) does nothing if len >= arr.get_size.

docs.title: _debug_print_to_stream : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::String -> ()
docs.text:
Prints a string to the specified stream and flushes the stream.

NOTE: This function is not pure and should only be used for temporary debugging purposes.

docs.title: assert : Std::Lazy Std::String -> Std::Bool -> Std::IO ()
docs.text:
Asserts that a condition (boolean value) is true.

If the assertion failed, prints a message to the stderr and aborts the program.

docs.title: assert_eq : [a : Std::Eq] Std::Lazy Std::String -> a -> a -> Std::IO ()
docs.text:
Asserts that two values are equal.

If the assertion failed, prints a message to the stderr and aborts the program.

docs.title: assert_unique : Std::Lazy Std::String -> a -> a
docs.text:
Asserts that the given value is unique, and returns the given value. If the assertion failed, prints a message to the stderr and aborts the program.

The main use of this function is to check whether a boxed value given as an argument is unique.

docs.title: _get_boxed_ptr : [a : Std::Boxed] a -> Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Returns a pointer to the data of a boxed value.

The returned pointer points to: - if the value is an Array, the first element of the array, - if the value is a struct, the first field, - if the value is an union, the data field (not the tag field).

The difference from boxed_to_retained_ptr is that this function returns a pointer to region where the payload of a boxed value is stored; on the other hand, boxed_to_retained_ptr returns a pointer to the boxed value itself (which currently points to the reference counter of the boxed value).

NOTE: This function is unsafe in that if the call v._get_boxed_ptr is the last usage of v, then this function deallocates v and returns a dangling pointer. To avoid this issue, use borrow_boxed, borrow_boxed_io, mutate_boxed, or mutate_boxed_io instead.

docs.title: borrow_boxed : [a : Std::Boxed] (Std::Ptr -> b) -> a -> b
docs.text:
Borrows a pointer to the data of a boxed value.

For the details of the pointer, see the document of _get_boxed_ptr.

docs.title: borrow_boxed_io : [a : Std::Boxed] (Std::Ptr -> Std::IO b) -> a -> Std::IO b
docs.text:
Performs an IO action borrowing a pointer to the data of a boxed value.

For the details of the pointer, see the document of _get_boxed_ptr.

docs.title: boxed_from_retained_ptr : [a : Std::Boxed] Std::Ptr -> a
docs.text:
Creates a boxed value from a retained pointer obtained by boxed_to_retained_ptr.

NOTE: It is the user's responsibility to ensure that the argument is actually a pointer to the type of the return value, and undefined behavior will occur if it is not.

docs.title: boxed_to_retained_ptr : [a : Std::Boxed] a -> Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Returns a retained pointer to a boxed value. This function is used to share ownership of Fix's boxed values with foreign languages.

To get back the boxed value from the retained pointer, use from_retained_ptr. To release / retain the value in a foreign language, call the function pointer obtained by get_funptr_release or get_funptr_retain on the pointer.

Note that the returned pointer points to the control block allocated by Fix, and does not necessary points to the data of the boxed value. If you want to get a pointer to the data of the boxed value, use borrow_boxed.

docs.title: clear_errno : Std::IO ()
docs.text: Sets errno to zero.

docs.title: get_errno : Std::IO Std::FFI::CInt
docs.text: Gets errno which is set by C functions.

docs.title: get_funptr_release : [a : Std::Boxed] Std::Lazy a -> Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Returns a pointer to the function of type void (*)(void*) which releases a boxed value of type a. This function is used to release a pointer obtained by boxed_to_retained_ptr.

Note that this function is requires a value of type Lazy a, not of a. So you can get release function for a boxed type T even when you don't have a value of type T -- you can just use |_| undefined("") : T:

module Main;

type VoidType = box struct {};
// No constructor for `VoidType` is provided.

main: IO ();
main = (
    let release = (|_| undefined("") : VoidType).get_funptr_release; // Release function of `VoidType`.
    pure()
);

docs.title: get_funptr_retain : [a : Std::Boxed] Std::Lazy a -> Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Returns a pointer to the function of type void (*)(void*) which retains a boxed value of type a. This function is used to retain a pointer obtained by boxed_to_retained_ptr.

For the reason that this function requires a value of type Lazy a, not of a, see the document for get_funptr_release.

docs.title: mutate_boxed : [a : Std::Boxed] (Std::Ptr -> Std::IO b) -> a -> (a, b)
docs.text:
x.mutate_boxed(io) gets a pointer ptr to the data that x points to, executes io(ptr), and then returns mutated x paired with the result of io(ptr).

The IO action io(ptr) is expected to modify the value of x through the obtained pointer. Do not perform any IO operations other than mutating the value of x.

For more details on the value of the pointer passed to io, see the document of _get_boxed_ptr.

This function first clones the value if x is not unique.

docs.title: mutate_boxed_io : [a : Std::Boxed] (Std::Ptr -> Std::IO b) -> a -> Std::IO (a, b)
docs.text:
x.mutate_boxed_io(io) gets a pointer ptr to the data that x points to, executes io(ptr), and then returns mutated x paired with the result of io(ptr).

Similar to mutate_boxed, but this function is used when you want to run the IO action in the existing IO context.

For more details, see the document of mutate_boxed.

docs.title: mutate_boxed_ios : [a : Std::Boxed] (Std::Ptr -> Std::IO b) -> a -> Std::IO::IOState -> (Std::IO::IOState, (a, b))
docs.text: Internal implementation of the mutate_boxed_io function.

docs.title: borrow : (a -> b) -> Std::FFI::Destructor a -> b
docs.text:
Borrow the contained value.

borrow(worker, dtor) calls worker on the contained value captured by dtor, and returns the value returned by worker.

It is guaranteed that the dtor is alive during the call of worker. In other words, the worker receives the contained value for which the destructor is not called yet.

docs.title: borrow_io : (a -> Std::IO b) -> Std::FFI::Destructor a -> Std::IO b
docs.text: Performs an IO action borrowing the contained value.

docs.title: make : a -> (a -> Std::IO a) -> Std::FFI::Destructor a
docs.text: Make a destructor value.

docs.title: mutate_unique : (a -> Std::IO a) -> (a -> Std::IO b) -> Std::FFI::Destructor a -> (Std::FFI::Destructor a, b)
docs.text:
Apply an IO action which mutates the semantics of the value.

dtor.mutate_unique(ctor, action) applies action to dtor if dtor is unique. If dtor is shared, it creates a new Destructor value using ctor and applies action to the new value.

The action is allowed to modify the external resource stored in dtor (e.g., if value is a pointer, it can modify the value pointed by the pointer). Also, ctor should be a "copy constructor" (e.g., memcpy) of the external resource stored in dtor.

docs.title: mutate_unique_io : (a -> Std::IO a) -> (a -> Std::IO b) -> Std::FFI::Destructor a -> Std::IO (Std::FFI::Destructor a, b)
docs.text:
Apply an IO action which mutates the semantics of the value.

This is similar to mutate_unique, but the ctor and action is executed in the context of the external IO context.

docs.title: _read_line_inner : Std::Bool -> Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO::IOFail Std::String
docs.text:
Reads characters from an IOHandle.

If the first argument upto_newline is true, this function reads a file upto newline or EOF.

docs.title: close_file : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO ()
docs.text:
Closes a file.

Unlike C's fclose, closing an already closed IOHandle is safe and does nothing.

docs.title: eprint : Std::String -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: Prints a string to stderr.

docs.title: eprintln : Std::String -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: Prints a string followed by a newline to stderr.

docs.title: exit : Std::I64 -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Exits the program with an error code.

docs.title: exit_with_msg : Std::I64 -> Std::String -> Std::IO a
docs.text:
Exits the program with an error message and an error code.

The error message is written to the standard error output.

docs.title: from_runner : (Std::IO::IOState -> (Std::IO::IOState, a)) -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Creates an IO action from a IO runner function, which is a function of type IOState -> (IOState, a).

docs.title: get_arg : Std::I64 -> Std::IO (Std::Option Std::String)
docs.text:
get_arg(n) returns the n-th (0-indexed) command line argument.

If n is greater than or equal to the number of command line arguments, this function returns none.

docs.title: get_arg_count : Std::IO Std::I64
docs.text: Gets the number of command line arguments.

docs.title: get_args : Std::IO (Std::Array Std::String)
docs.text: Gets command line arguments.

docs.title: input_line : Std::IO Std::String
docs.text:
Reads a line from stdin. If some error occurr, this function aborts the program.

If you want to handle errors, use read_line(stdin) instead.

docs.title: is_eof : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO Std::Bool
docs.text: Checks if an IOHandle reached to the EOF.

docs.title: loop_lines : Std::IO::IOHandle -> s -> (s -> Std::String -> Std::LoopState s s) -> Std::IO::IOFail s
docs.text:
Loop on lines read from an IOHandle.

loop_lines(handle, initial_state, worker) calls worker on the pair of current state and a line string read from handle. The function worker should return an updated state as LoopState value, i.e., a value created by continue or break. When the handle reaches to the EOF or worker returns a break value, loop_lines returns the last state value.

Note that the line string passed to worker may contain a newline code at the end. To remove it, use String::strip_last_spaces.

docs.title: loop_lines_io : Std::IO::IOHandle -> s -> (s -> Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::LoopState s s)) -> Std::IO::IOFail s
docs.text:
Loop on lines read from an IOHandle.

Similar to loop_lines, but the worker function can perform an IO action.

docs.title: open_file : Std::Path -> Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail Std::IO::IOHandle
docs.text: Openes a file. The second argument is a mode string for fopen C function.

docs.title: print : Std::String -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: Prints a string to stdout.

docs.title: println : Std::String -> Std::IO ()
docs.text: Prints a string followed by a newline to stdout.

docs.title: read_bytes : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::Array Std::U8)
docs.text: Reads all bytes from an IOHandle.

docs.title: read_file_bytes : Std::Path -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::Array Std::U8)
docs.text: Reads all bytes from a file.

docs.title: read_file_string : Std::Path -> Std::IO::IOFail Std::String
docs.text: Raads all characters from a file.

docs.title: read_line : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO::IOFail Std::String
docs.text: Reads characters from a IOHandle upto newline or EOF. The returned string may include newline at its end.

docs.title: read_n_bytes : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::I64 -> Std::IO::IOFail (Std::Array Std::U8)
docs.text: Reads at most n bytes from an IOHandle.

docs.title: read_string : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO::IOFail Std::String
docs.text: Reads all characters from an IOHandle.

docs.title: stderr : Std::IO::IOHandle
docs.text: The handle for standard error.

docs.title: stdin : Std::IO::IOHandle
docs.text: The handle for standard input.

docs.title: stdout : Std::IO::IOHandle
docs.text: The handle for standard output.

docs.title: with_file : Std::Path -> Std::String -> (Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO::IOFail a) -> Std::IO::IOFail a
docs.text:
Performs a function with a file handle. The second argument is a mode string for fopen C function.

The file handle will be closed automatically.

docs.title: write_bytes : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Writes a byte array into an IOHandle.

docs.title: write_file_bytes : Std::Path -> Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Writes a byte array into a file.

docs.title: write_file_string : Std::Path -> Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Writes a string into a file.

docs.title: write_string : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail ()
docs.text: Writes a string into an IOHandle.

docs.title: from_io_result : Std::IO (Std::Result Std::ErrMsg a) -> Std::IO::IOFail a
docs.text: Create from IO action of which returns Result ErrMsg a.

docs.title: from_result : Std::Result Std::ErrMsg a -> Std::IO::IOFail a
docs.text: Creates an pure IOFail value from a Result value.

docs.title: lift : Std::IO a -> Std::IO::IOFail a
docs.text: Lifts an IO action to a successful IOFail action.

docs.title: throw : Std::ErrMsg -> Std::IO::IOFail a
docs.text: Creates an error IOFail action.

docs.title: to_result : Std::IO::IOFail a -> Std::IO (Std::Result Std::ErrMsg a)
docs.text: Converts an IOFail to an Result value (wrapped by IO).

docs.title: try : (Std::ErrMsg -> Std::IO a) -> Std::IO::IOFail a -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Converts an IOFail value to an IO value by an error handler (i.e., a catch) function.

docs.title: _file_ptr : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Gets pointer to C's FILE value from an IOHandle.

If the IOHandle is already closed, the function returns nullptr.

NOTE: Do not directly close the file pointer by fclose or other functions. Instead you should close IOHandle by IO::close_file.

DEPRECATED: Use get_file_ptr instead. This function is deprecated because it has a pure function interface, but the value of _file_ptr changes by calling IO::close_file.

docs.title: from_file_ptr : Std::Ptr -> Std::IO::IOHandle
docs.text:
Creates an IOHandle from a file pointer (i.e., pointer to C's FILE).

Creating two IOHandles from a single file pointer is forbidden.

docs.title: get_file_ptr : Std::IO::IOHandle -> Std::IO Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Gets pointer to C's FILE value from an IOHandle.

If the IOHandle is already closed, the function returns nullptr.

NOTE: Do not directly close the file pointer by fclose or other functions. Instead you should close IOHandle by IO::close_file.

NOTE: If IO::close is called while using the Ptr obtained by this function, the Ptr becomes invalid and may cause undefined behavior.

docs.title: append : [i1 : Std::Iterator, i2 : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i1 = a, Std::Iterator::Item i2 = a] i2 -> i1 -> Std::Iterator::AppendIterator i1 i2
docs.text:
Append two iterators.

NOTE: Since this function is designed so that iter1.append(iter2) appends iter2 after iter1, append(iter1, iter2) appends iterators in the opposite order.

docs.title: bang : [iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] iter -> Std::Iterator::ArrayIterator a
docs.text:
Convert any iterator to an array iterator.

All elements of the input iterator are collected into an array. Therefore, this function may consume a lot of memory. On the other hand, iteration may be faster by banging.

docs.title: collect_m : [m : Std::Monad, iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = m a] iter -> m (Std::Array a)
docs.text: Executes monadic actions and collects the results into an array.

docs.title: count_up : Std::I64 -> Std::Iterator::CountUpIterator
docs.text:
Create an iterator that counts up from a number.

count_up(start) generates an infinite sequence of numbers starting from start.

docs.title: empty : Std::Iterator::EmptyIterator a
docs.text:
An iterator that yields no elements.

NOTE: When using this iterator, you may need to specify the type of the iterator explicitly, e.g, (empty : EmptyIterator I64).

docs.title: filter : [i : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i = a] (a -> Std::Bool) -> i -> Std::Iterator::FilterIterator i a
docs.text:
Filter the elements of an iterator by a predicate.

iter.filter(pred) returns an iterator that only yields elements of iter for which pred returns true.

docs.title: filter_map : [i : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i = a] (a -> Std::Option b) -> i -> Std::Iterator::FilterMapIterator i a b
docs.text:
Filter and map the elements of an iterator.

iter.filter_map(f) returns an iterator that applies f to each element of iter and yields the result if it is some.

docs.title: flat_map : [i1 : Std::Iterator, i2 : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i1 = a, Std::Iterator::Item i2 = b] (a -> i2) -> i1 -> Std::Iterator::FlatMapIterator i1 a i2
flatten : [i2 : Std::Iterator, i1 : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i2 = i1] i2 -> Std::Iterator::FlattenIterator i2 i1
docs.text: Flatten an iterator of iterators.

docs.title: fold : [iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] s -> (a -> s -> s) -> iter -> s
docs.text:
Fold the elements of an iterator from left to right.

Conceptually, [a0, a1, a2, ...].to_iter.fold(s, op) = s.op(a0).op(a1).op(a2)....

docs.title: fold_m : [m : Std::Monad, iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] s -> (a -> s -> m s) -> iter -> m s
docs.text: Fold the elements of an iterator from left to right by monadic action.

docs.title: from_array : Std::Array a -> Std::Iterator::ArrayIterator a
docs.text: Create an iterator from an array.

docs.title: from_map : (Std::I64 -> a) -> Std::Iterator::MapIterator Std::Iterator::CountUpIterator Std::I64 a
docs.text: Create an iterator by a function that returns element at each index.

docs.title: generate : s -> (s -> Std::Option (s, a)) -> Std::Iterator::StateIterator s a
docs.text: Create an iterator that generates elements by the state transition function.

docs.title: get_first : [iter : Std::Iterator] iter -> Std::Option (Std::Iterator::Item iter)
docs.text:
Get the first element of an iterator.

If the iterator is empty, this function returns none.

docs.title: get_size : [iter : Std::Iterator] iter -> Std::I64
docs.text: Get the number of elements in an iterator.

docs.title: get_tail : [iter : Std::Iterator] iter -> Std::Option iter
docs.text:
Get the tail of an iterator.

If the iterator is empty, this function returns none.

docs.title: intersperse : [i : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i = a] a -> i -> Std::Iterator::IntersperseIterator i a
docs.text:
Intersperse an element between elements of an iterator.

Example:

assert_eq(|_|"", [1, 2, 3].from_array.intersperse(0).to_array, [1, 0, 2, 0, 3]);;

docs.title: is_empty : [iter : Std::Iterator] iter -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Is an iterator empty?

docs.title: is_equal : [iter1 : Std::Iterator, iter2 : Std::Iterator, a : Std::Eq, Std::Iterator::Item iter1 = a, Std::Iterator::Item iter2 = a] iter1 -> iter2 -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Compare two iterators by their elements.

docs.title: loop_iter : [iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] s -> (a -> s -> Std::LoopState s s) -> iter -> s
docs.text:
Loop over the elements of an iterator.

This function is similar to fold but a more general version of it. It allows the user to break out of the loop at any point.

docs.title: loop_iter_m : [m : Std::Monad, iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] s -> (a -> s -> m (Std::LoopState s s)) -> iter -> m s
docs.text: Loop over the elements of an iterator by monadic action.

docs.title: map : [i : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i = a] (a -> b) -> i -> Std::Iterator::MapIterator i a b
docs.text:
Map a function over an iterator.

iter.map(f) returns an iterator that applies f to each element of iter.

docs.title: pop_first : [iter : Std::Iterator] iter -> iter
docs.text:
Remove the first element of an iterator.

If the iterator is empty, this function does nothing.

docs.title: product : [i1 : Std::Iterator, i2 : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i1 = a, Std::Iterator::Item i2 = b] i2 -> i1 -> Std::Iterator::ProductIterator i1 i2 a b
docs.text:
Create an iterator that yields the Cartesian product of two iterators.

NOTE: Since this function is designed so that iter1.product(iter2) yields the Cartesian product, the elements of product(iter2, iter1) are in the opposite order.

Example:

assert_eq(|_|"", range(1, 4).product(['a', 'b'].from_array).to_array, [(1, 'a'), (2, 'a'), (3, 'a'), (1, 'b'), (2, 'b'), (3, 'b')]);;

docs.title: push_front : [i : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i = a] a -> i -> Std::Iterator::ConsIterator i a
docs.text: Push an element to an iterator.

docs.title: range : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Iterator::RangeIterator
docs.text:
Create an iterator that generates a range of numbers.

range(a, b) generates a range of numbers from a to b - 1.

If a is greater than or equal to b, the iterator will an infinite sequence of a.

docs.title: range_step : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::Iterator::RangeStepIterator
docs.text: Create an iterator that generates a range of numbers with a step.

docs.title: reverse : [i : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i = a] i -> Std::Iterator::ReverseIterator i a
docs.text:
Reverses an iterator.

NOTE: This function puts all elements of the iterator into an array, so it may consume a lot of memory.

docs.title: sum : [iter : Std::Iterator, a : Std::Additive, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] iter -> a
docs.text: Calcculate sum of the elements of an iterator.

docs.title: take : [i : Std::Iterator] Std::I64 -> i -> Std::Iterator::TakeIterator i
docs.text: Take the first n elements of an iterator.

docs.title: take_while : [i : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item i = a] (a -> Std::Bool) -> i -> Std::Iterator::TakeWhileIterator i a
docs.text: Take elements from an iterator while a predicate holds.

docs.title: to_array : [iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] iter -> Std::Array a
docs.text: Convert an iterator to an array.

docs.title: to_dyn : [iter : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item iter = a] iter -> Std::Iterator::DynIterator a
docs.text: Convert an iterator into a dynamic iterator.

docs.title: zip : [i1 : Std::Iterator, i2 : Std::Iterator] i2 -> i1 -> Std::Iterator::ZipIterator i1 i2
docs.text:
Zip two iterators.

NOTE: Since this function is designed so that iter1.zip(iter2) zips iter1 and iter2, the elements of zip(iter2, iter1) are in the opposite order.

docs.title: empty : Std::Iterator::DynIterator a
docs.text: Creates an empty dynamic iterator.

docs.title: less_than : [a : Std::LessThan] a -> a -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Compares two values. An expression x < y is translated to less_than(x, y).

docs.title: less_than_or_eq : [a : Std::LessThanOrEq] a -> a -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Compares two values. An expression x <= y is translated to less_than_or_eq(x, y).

docs.title: break_m : [m : Std::Monad] r -> m (Std::LoopState s r)
docs.text:
Make a break value wrapped in a monad.

This is used with loop_m function.

docs.title: continue_m : [m : Std::Monad] s -> m (Std::LoopState s r)
docs.text:
Make a continue value wrapped in a monad.

This is used with loop_m function.

docs.title: bind : [m : Std::Monad] (a -> m b) -> m a -> m b
flatten : [m : Std::Monad] m (m a) -> m a
docs.text: Flattens a nested monadic action.

docs.title: unless : [m : Std::Monad] Std::Bool -> m () -> m ()
docs.text: unless(cond, act) where act is a monadic value which returns () perfoms act only when cond is false.

docs.title: when : [m : Std::Monad] Std::Bool -> m () -> m ()
docs.text: when(cond, act) where act is a monadic value which returns () perfoms act only when cond is true.

docs.title: mul : [a : Std::Mul] a -> a -> a
docs.text: Multiplies a value by another value. An expression x * y is translated to mul(x, y).

docs.title: neg : [a : Std::Neg] a -> a
docs.text: Negates a value. An expression -x is translated to neg(x).

docs.title: not : [a : Std::Not] a -> a
docs.text: Logical NOT of a value. An expression !x is translated to not(x).

docs.title: as_some_or : a -> Std::Option a -> a
docs.text: Unwrap an option value if it is some, or returns given default value if it is none.

docs.title: map_or : b -> (a -> b) -> Std::Option a -> b
docs.text: Returns the provided default value if the option is none, or applies a function to the contained value if the option is some.

docs.title: to_iter : Std::Option a -> Std::Option::OptionIterator (Std::Option a)
docs.text: Converts an option into an iterator.

docs.title: add_offset : Std::I64 -> Std::Ptr -> Std::Ptr
docs.text: Adds an offset to a pointer.

docs.title: subtract_ptr : Std::Ptr -> Std::Ptr -> Std::I64
docs.text:
Subtracts two pointers.

Note that x.subtract_ptr(y) calculates x - y, so subtract_ptr(x, y) calculates y - x.

docs.title: plug_in : a -> Std::PunchedArray a -> Std::Array a
docs.text: Plug in an element to a punched array to get back an array.

docs.title: unsafe_punch : Std::I64 -> Std::Array a -> (Std::PunchedArray a, a)
docs.text:
Creates a punched array by moving out the element at the specified index.

NOTE: this function assumes that the given array is unique WITHOUT CHECKING. The uniqueness of the array is ensured in the Array::act function.

docs.title: rem : [a : Std::Rem] a -> a -> a
docs.text: Calculate remainder of a value dividing another value. An expression x % y is translated to rem(x, y).

docs.title: unwrap : Std::Result e o -> o
docs.text: Returns the containing value if the value is ok, or otherwise aborts the program.

docs.title: _get_c_str : Std::String -> Std::Ptr
docs.text:
Get the null-terminated C string.

Note that in case the string is not used after call of this function, the returned pointer will be already released.

docs.title: _unsafe_from_c_str : Std::Array Std::U8 -> Std::String
docs.text:
Create a string from C string (i.e., null-terminated byte array).

If the byte array doesn't include \0, this function causes undefined behavior.

docs.title: _unsafe_from_c_str_ptr : Std::Ptr -> Std::String
docs.text:
Create a String from a pointer to null-terminated C string.

If ptr is not pointing to a valid null-terminated C string, this function cause undefined behavior.

docs.title: borrow_c_str : (Std::Ptr -> a) -> Std::String -> a
docs.text: Call a function with a null-terminated C string.

docs.title: borrow_c_str_io : (Std::Ptr -> Std::IO a) -> Std::String -> Std::IO a
docs.text: Call an IO action with a null-terminated C string.

docs.title: concat : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text:
Concatenate two strings.

Note: Since s1.concat(s2) puts s2 after s1, concat(lhs, rhs) puts lhs after rhs.

docs.title: concat_iter : [strs : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item strs = Std::String] strs -> Std::String
docs.text: Concatenate an iterator of strings.

docs.title: empty : Std::I64 -> Std::String
docs.text: Create an empty string, which is reserved for a length.

docs.title: find : Std::String -> Std::I64 -> Std::String -> Std::Option Std::I64
docs.text:
str.find(token, start_idx) finds the index where token firstly appears in str, starting from start_idx.

Note that this function basically returns a number less than or equal to start_idx, but there is an exception: str.find("", start_idx) with start_idx >= str.get_size returns str.get_size, not start_idx.

docs.title: from_U8 : Std::U8 -> Std::String
docs.text:
Creates a string from a byte.

Example:

assert_eq(|_|"", String::from_U8('a'), "a");;
assert_eq(|_|"", String::from_U8('\x00'), "");;

docs.title: get_bytes : Std::String -> Std::Array Std::U8
docs.text: Gets the byte array of a string, containing null-terminator.

docs.title: get_first_byte : Std::String -> Std::Option Std::U8
docs.text: Gets the first byte of a string. Returns none if the string is empty.

docs.title: get_last_byte : Std::String -> Std::Option Std::U8
docs.text: Gets the last byte of a string. Returns none if the string is empty.

docs.title: get_size : Std::String -> Std::I64
docs.text: Gets the length of a string.

docs.title: get_sub : Std::I64 -> Std::I64 -> Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text: String version of Array::get_sub.

docs.title: is_empty : Std::String -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Returns if the string is empty or not.

docs.title: join : [ss : Std::Iterator, Std::Iterator::Item ss = Std::String] Std::String -> ss -> Std::String
docs.text: Joins (an iterator of) strings by a separator.

docs.title: pop_back_byte : Std::String -> Std::String
docs.text:
Removes the last byte.

If the string is empty, this function does nothing.

docs.title: split : Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::String::StringSplitIterator
docs.text:
str.split(sep) splits str by sep into an iterator.

Example:

assert_eq(|_|"Ex. 1", "ab,c,".split(",").to_array, ["ab", "c", ""]);;
assert_eq(|_|"Ex. 2", "abc".split(",").to_array, ["abc"]);;
assert_eq(|_|"Ex. 3", "abc".split("").to_array, ["a", "b", "c"]);; // Special behavior when the separator is empty.

docs.title: strip_first_bytes : (Std::U8 -> Std::Bool) -> Std::String -> Std::String

docs.title: strip_spaces : Std::String -> Std::String

You can create a lazy value by |_| (...an expression to generate the value...), and you can evaluate a lazy value v by v().

A union type with variants continue and break.

This type is used to represent the result of a loop body function passed to Std::loop or other similar functions.

docs.text:
The type of punched arrays.

A punched array is an array from which a certain element has been removed. This is used in the implementation of Array::act.

docs.title: type Result e o = unbox union { ...variants... }
docs.text: A type of result value for a computation that may fail.

docs.title: type Tuple3 t0 t1 t2 = unbox struct { ...fields... }
type U16 = unbox { built-in }
docs.text: The type of 16-bit unsigned integers.

docs.title: type U32 = unbox { built-in }
docs.text: The type of 32-bit unsigned integers.

docs.title: type U64 = unbox { built-in }
docs.text: The type of 64-bit unsigned integers.

docs.title: type U8 = unbox { built-in }
docs.text: The type of 8-bit unsinged integers.

docs.title: type Destructor a = box struct { ...fields... }
docs.text:
Destructor a is a wrapper type for a, which can have a destructor function a -> IO a. Just before a value of type Destructor a is dropped, the destructor function is called on the contained value, and the value can be modified by the IO action.

This type is used to create a Fix's type that wraps a resource allocated by FFI. In such cases, the destructor release the resource by FFI.

NOTE: In the destructor, only IO actions for finalizing the passed value are allowed, and you should not perform other IO actions such as writing standard output.

NOTE: Of course, if the value stored in Destructor also exists outside of Destructor, the value still exists in the Fix program even after the destructor function is called, and there is a possibility that the value is used after the destructor function is called.

docs.title: type IOFail a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: The type for I/O actions which may fail.

docs.title: type IOHandle = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text:
A handle type for read / write operations on files, stdin, stdout, stderr.

You can create IOHandle value by IO::open_file, and close it by IO::close_file. There are also global IO::IOHandle::stdin, IO::IOHandle::stdout, IO::IOHandle::stderr.

IOHandle is different from C's FILE structure in that it is safe to close it twice. If you try to get a file pointer by file_ptr from a closed IOHandle, you will get nullptr.

NOTE: IOHandle is implemented by Destructor, but the destructor function does not close the file pointer. (The destructor function only frees the management memory area.) You should explicitly close the file pointer by IO::close_file.

docs.title: type IOState = unbox { built-in }
docs.text:
The type of the "state"s modified by I/O operations.

The type IO a is isomorphic to IOState -> (IOState, a).

Values of type IOState must be used linearly, i.e., each value must be used exactly once and must not be duplicated or discarded.

Values of type IOState are generated by the runtime when executing IO actions like main and passed linearly to various places in the program. At some places, IOState values are consumed by FFI_CALL_IOS expressions and new IOState values are generated. When IO actions like main finish, they are consumed by the runtime and disappear.

Technically, IOState exists to specify the execution of I/O operations to the optimizer in the compiler.

docs.title: type ArrayIterator a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: Iterators that yields elements of an array.

docs.title: type DynIterator a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text:
The type of dynamic iterators.

DynIterator has a field, next, which is a function that returns the next element and the next iterator. Therefore, the process to advance DynIterator can be determined dynamically at runtime, not at compile time.

The main advantage of dynamic iterator is that since it has a simple type, DynIterator a, - DynIterator can be instances of traits such as Monad, Eq, etc. - it is possible to return two dynamic iterators with different constructions depending on the branch.

However, iterating over DynIterator are much slower than iterating over other iterators provided in this namespace. Therefore, if performance is important, you should avoid using DynIterator. In particular, if you iterate over the same DynIterator multiple times, consider converting it to an ArrayIterator using bang before iterating.

docs.title: type EmptyIterator a = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: Iterators that yields no elements.

docs.title: type FilterMapIterator i a b = unbox struct { ...fields... }
type FlatMapIterator = Std::Iterator::FlattenIterator (Std::Iterator::MapIterator i1 a i2) i2
type MapIterator i a b = unbox struct { ...fields... }
type ProductIterator i1 i2 a b = unbox struct { ...fields... }
type RangeIterator = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: Iterators that yields reversed elements of an iterator.

docs.title: type TakeIterator i = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: Takes at most n elements from an iterator.

docs.text:
The trait of iterators.

Iterator is a concept of a sequence of elements that can be iterated. More precisely, an iterator is a type whose data is "the current state" and has a method advance which returns the next element and the next state.

docs.title: trait a : LessThan
docs.text: Trait for infix operator <.

docs.title: method less_than : a -> a -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Compares two values. An expression x < y is translated to less_than(x, y).

docs.title: method less_than_or_eq : a -> a -> Std::Bool
docs.text: Compares two values. An expression x <= y is translated to less_than_or_eq(x, y).

docs.title: run_string : Std::String -> Std::Array Std::String -> Std::String -> Std::IO::IOFail ((Std::String, Std::String), Subprocess::ExitStatus)
docs.text:
run_string(com, args, input) executes a command specified by com with arguments args, and writes input to the standard input of the running command.

The result is the pair of standard output and standard error, and an ExitStatus value.

docs.title: run_with_stream : Std::String -> Std::Array Std::String -> ((Std::IO::IOHandle, Std::IO::IOHandle, Std::IO::IOHandle) -> Std::IO::IOFail a) -> Std::IO::IOFail (a, Subprocess::ExitStatus)
docs.text:
run_with_stream(com, args, worker) executes a command specified by com with arguments args.

The function worker receives three IOHandles which are piped to the stdin, stdout and stderr of the running command.

The result is the value returned by worker paired with an ExitStatus value. - com : String: The path to the program to run. - args: Array String: The arguments to be passed to com. - worker : (IOHandle, IOHandle, IOHandle) -> IOFail a: Receives three IOHandles which are piped to stdin, stdout and stderr of the running command.

docs.title: type ExitStatus = box union { ...variants... }
docs.text:
This type represents the exit status of a subprocess.

This type is the union of following variants: * exit : U8 - Means that the subprocess successfully exited (i.e., the main function returned or exit() was called) and stores the exit status code. * signaled : U8 - Means that the subprocess was terminated by a signal and stores the signal number which caused the termination. * wait_failed : () - Means that the run* function failed to wait the subprocess to exit.

This struct is used in the internal implementation.

docs.title: _datetime_to_time_inner : Std::Bool -> Time::DateTime -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg Time::Time
docs.text: Convert datetime to time. _datetime_to_time_inner(false) treats the argument as UTC datetime, and _datetime_to_time_inner(true) treats the argument as local datetime. Note that "local time" depends on timezone, so this function is violating purity.

docs.title: _time_to_datetime_inner : Std::Bool -> Time::Time -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg Time::DateTime
docs.text: Convert time to datetime. _time_to_datetime_inner(false) returns utc datetime, and _time_to_datetime_inner(true) returns local datetime. Note that "local time" depends on timezone, so this function is violating purity.

docs.title: from_local : Time::DateTime -> Std::IO::IOFail Time::Time
docs.text: Convert local datetime to time. This function depends on timezone, so it returns IOFail value.

docs.title: from_utc : Time::DateTime -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg Time::Time
docs.text: Convert UTC datetime to time.

docs.title: get_now : Std::IO Time::Time
docs.text: Get current time.

docs.title: get_now_monotonic : Std::IO Time::Time
docs.text: Get current time using CLOCK_MONOTONIC.

docs.title: to_F64 : Time::Time -> Std::F64
docs.text: Convert time to 64-bit floating value.

docs.title: to_local : Time::Time -> Std::IO::IOFail Time::DateTime
docs.text: Convert time to local time. This function depends on timezone, so it returns IOFail value.

docs.title: to_utc : Time::Time -> Std::Result Std::ErrMsg Time::DateTime
docs.text: Convert time to UTC datetime.

docs.title: type DateTime = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: The type to represent date and time.

docs.title: type Time = unbox struct { ...fields... }
docs.text: The type that represents time by the number of seconds and micro seconds elapsed since the unix epoch. This struct has two fields, sec: I64 and nanosec: U32.
